article_tags: [Arctic, Environment, Climate change, US news]
description: Sea ice has hit record lows for time of year as experts say global warming probably fueled big storms in Europe and north-eastern US
headline: d
og_fields.og:description: Sea ice has hit record lows for time of year as experts say global warming probably fueled big storms in Europe and north-eastern US
og_fields.og:title: Arctic has warmest winter on record: 'It's just crazy, crazy stuff'
text:
The Arctic winter has ended with more news that is worrying even the scientists who watch the effects of climate change closely.
The region experienced its warmest winter on record. Sea ice hit record lows for the time of year, new US weather data revealed on Tuesday.
“It’s just crazy, crazy stuff,” said Mark Serreze, director of the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Boulder, Colorado, who has been studying the Arctic since 1982. “These heat waves – I’ve never seen anything like this.”
Experts say what’s happening is unprecedented, part of a global warming-driven cycle that probably played a role in the recent strong, icy storms in Europe and the north-eastern US.
The land weather station closest to the North Pole, at the tip of Greenland, spent more than 60 hours above freezing in February. Before this year, scientists had seen the temperature there rise above freezing in February only twice before, and then extremely briefly. Last month’s record-high temperatures have been more like those typical of May, said Ruth Mottram, a climate scientist at the Danish Meteorological Institute.
Of nearly three dozen different Arctic weather stations, 15 of them were at least 10F (5.6C) above normal for the winter.
“The extended warmth really has staggered all of us,” Mottram said. 
In February, Arctic sea ice covered 5.4m sq miles, about 62,000 sq miles smaller than last year’s record low, the ice data center reported, and it was 521,000 square miles below the 30-year normal.
Sea ice is frozen ocean water that, in contrast to icebergs and glaciers, forms, grows and melts on the ocean. It is still growing, but “whatever we grow now is going to be thin stuff” that easily melts in the summer, Serreze said.
Something similar has been noted in the Pacific with open water on the normally iced-up Bering Sea, said the data center senior scientist Walt Meier. To be happening on opposite sides of the Arctic at the same time was unusual, he added.
“Climate change is the overriding thing,” Meier said.

[{u'author': u'JimW99', u'text': u'Fortunately, methane is broken down by sunlight and only persists for about 10 years, unlike Co2, which is stable and can last for 1,000s of years.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520536379000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100032735', u'in_reply_to': u'113079602', u'id': u'113283388', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JimW99', u'text': u'C02 is going up at a steady 2 ppm per year. If that continues, not considering potential acceleration, we will indeed be well over 600 ppm within 100 years. The eventual temperature increase to go along with that will be in the range of 3 to 4 C above today (4 to 5 C above pre-industrial). That, combined with 1 to 2 meters of sea level rise will gradually render large parts of the Earth uninhabitable with climate refugees numbering in the billions. Fortunately for me, I only have about 30 years at most left on this planet, so I won't live to see the worst of it. On the other hand, if we take enough action to curb fossil fuel emissions and get them near zero by mid-century, we can probably keep CO2 under 500 ppm and reduce (but not eliminate) much of the pain and suffering that is to come.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520534981000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100032735', u'in_reply_to': u'113205352', u'id': u'113282726', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EcoNihilist', u'text': u'I can recommend helium.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520529278000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18218700', u'in_reply_to': u'113278714', u'id': u'113279326', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Do you have a web site pushing them? But eco nihilist approved ones only.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520524475000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'113213191', u'id': u'113275288', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'The problem is "urgent" but not a panic, i.e. not "desperate". Your misuse of the word urgent here makes me wonder why you fly the flag of an English speaking nation. Get a good dictionary if you want to argue the toss about individual words.
Fracking involves injection of a sand and chemical mix in water to break up shale and force out the oil. After this has been done the waste water (fairly toxic mix) has to be disposed of. Rather than filter it, they re-inject the waste water, and usually below the level of ground water so that it won't contaminate same. A messy business that would not turn a profit without tax incentives.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520524029000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'113249874', u'id': u'113274938', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'Oh, yes, we've been talking at cross-purposes. I completely agree that human systems are very likely to be brittle in the way you describe and to have unpleasant and unpredictable failure modes. And such failures could easily be driven by the climate changing. Indeed I think it's really likely that such a nasty failure will happen at some point -- my 'nuclear war' scenario was intended to be the end-point of such a thing really -- food distribution breaks down in (say) the US rather abruptly as a result of (much slower) change in climate, a lot of people die, people with extreme nationalist political views take power, attempt some kind of land-grab for crops, fail, nuclear war, resulting huge insult to the climate system.
And as you say, something like a banking failure could lead to really sudden, really big problems: I don't think the people who argued that we should have let the banks fail in 2008 have really thought through the consequences of the financial system which makes sure their salary gets into their account and the ATMs work suddenly stopping working.
So, yes, I agree strongly with what you've said: sorry not to have read more carefully, & sorry if I was rude.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520520097000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'something like a banking failure', u'effect': u'really big problems'}], u'author_id': u'13299353', u'in_reply_to': u'113269937', u'id': u'113271770', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TTauriStellarbody', u'text': u'BQSTART
Global Warming is accelerating exponentially. The Earth could warm up 5 degrees in just 6 years or sooner. Nobody will survive that.
BQEND>>>>>>>>>>>>>>citation goes here<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520268351000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'113116039', u'id': u'113124864', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'Thank you for taking the time for such a thoughtful response. I fear I have not made myself clear. I completely agree with your analysis of climate stability; a good display of your clear understanding and knowledge. My point about systemic failure was aimed at human productive and logistical networks. In the U.K. a few years ago (forgive me I don’t know where you are from) the strike by fuel tanker drivers threaten food distribution. Indeed the strike became a threat to the fuel distribution network, posing hazard of a feedback induced logical failure.  When considering the huge network of interconnected systems that are needed to maintain productive and distributive capacity, it seems to me that there are a wide variety of vulnerabilities. Even a failure of an unreal system such as banking could lead to the loss of mutual exchange of goods and consequent disaster.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520517777000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'even a failure of an unreal system such as banking', u'effect': u'the loss of mutual exchange of goods and consequent disaster'}], u'author_id': u'17327071', u'in_reply_to': u'113266356', u'id': u'113269937', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'Computer systems are the canonical example of things which are extremely brittle: in a simple-minded computer system a significant proportion of physical changes which get large enough to flip a single bit will cause catastrophic failure of the system.
Some physical systems (computers are physical systems of course: if I had more space I would describe the difference more carefully) also have this kind of property, usually known as chaos or sensitive dependence on initial conditions (SDIC): tiny changes get blown up into huge later changes in the system. Weather, famously, is one such (which is why exponential increases in the computing power we can put into forecasting weather only result in roughly linear improvements in the time we can forecast it for).
Climate does not seem to be one of those systems: small changes in forcings tend to result in small changes to the climate. I am not sure if we understand mathematically why that is, or whether there are regions of the phase space of climate where there is SDIC (there almost certainly are: see below). But we have at least two sorts of experimental evidence that the climate is well-behaved in this sense: first of all we have quite good records of the way the climate behaved in the past, in particular during several cycles of glaciations & deglaciations, and it didn't fall off any cliffs, even when the total temperature swings were ~10 degrees. Secondly we can look around us and see life, and life depends on the climate not continually lashing about: trees, for instance, depend on changes being slow because they can't get up and walk to where the climate is more suitable for them, but have to creep around over hundreds or thousands of years by growing child trees in better places. And there are a lot of trees.
None of this means that there are not regions in the phase space where the climate does lash around wildly: as I said, almost certainly there are. But there's no real evidence that we're close to such a region. The most worrying thing is that we're pushing change into the system at a rate much faster than it has happened, almost ever (the event that killed the dinosaurs was faster: things like ice-ages were much slower, as was the PETM).
And even assuming the climate does not fall off a cliff in some way, the results of the changes driven by us are still very bad, of course.
In response to your comment about the US and food security: yes, obviously the US will not be the first country where a lot of people starve after harvests fail. They just might be the first one with a significant nuclear capability though, which was my point: no-one will care that billion poor people starve, they will care when a few million rich people do.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520513463000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a significant proportion of physical changes which get large enough to flip a single bit', u'effect': u'catastrophic failure of the system'}, {u'cause': u'exponential increases in the computing power we can put into forecasting weather', u'effect': u'roughly linear improvements in the time we can forecast it for'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'small changes to the climate'}, {u'cause': u"they ca n't get up and walk to where the climate is more suitable for them", u'effect': u'for instance depend on changes being slow but have to creep around over hundreds or thousands of years by growing child trees in better places'}], u'author_id': u'13299353', u'in_reply_to': u'113188148', u'id': u'113266356', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'"Nothing can avert our extinction now."More like angst-porn than rational evaluation. If you really think this, why are you even bothering to type this stuff? Go and have some fun, pump whatever crap you fancy into the atmosphere and then become extinct. Stop wasting your time proselytising about the supposedly 'inevitable'.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520265954000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'113116039', u'id': u'113122584', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MarkBLR', u'text': u'"Fascinating ..." (to coin a phrase).
I can't decide whether "Poe's Law" applies here or whether this is just a crude attempt by Boris / Vladimir / Natasha to discredit the "consensus" position.

BQSTART
all of the permafrost will thaw by 2100 and 20% will thaw by 2040
BQEND
Depending on the CO2 emissions "pathway" actually followed for the rest of this century, along with a whole host of currently unknown and unknowable factors / parameters, it is POSSIBLE that severe reductions in permafrost levels by 2100 COULD occur.
Use of the combination "all" and "will" is unjustified.

BQSTART
It will cause the world's average temperatures to warm up by at least 24 degrees Fahrenheit. That will happen in 22 years. ... The Earth could warm up 5 degrees in just 6 years or sooner.
BQEND
No it won't.
NB : I am supplying exactly the same amount of "supporting evidence", as it is known in scientific circles, for my assertions that you are.

BQSTART
Any action taken today will be a futile effort. It's too late.
BQEND
Isn't this one of the "5 stages of denial" outlined on SkS / RC ?!?

BQSTART
The Arctic is over 45 degrees Fahrenheit warmer than it should be.
BQEND
Check the DMI website for spikes in the "Daily mean temperatures for the Arctic area north of the 80th northern parallel" data that match the current one for both size (of deviation from the "normal" line) and duration (e.g. 1976, 1992, 2000 and 2006).
See also : The Holocene Climate Optimum (HCO) and the Eemian interglacial period.

BQSTART
The Arctic will lose all of it's ice this coming Summer
BQEND
Ah, you're NOT a Russian troll farm employee after all !
You are Peter Wadhams, and I claim my £5.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520265291000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u"the world 's average temperatures to warm up by at least 24 degrees fahrenheit"}], u'author_id': u'3985037', u'in_reply_to': u'113116039', u'id': u'113121971', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'curiouswes', u'text': u'BQSTART
The claims of massive ice loss by 2025 are in no way supported by any science.
BQEND
So in your view the problem is significant but not urgent?

BQEND
Don't the oil companies get kickbacks for researching renewables?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520482127000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12213899', u'in_reply_to': u'113234483', u'id': u'113249807', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JacopoManfredi', u'text': u'Hence my point - lots of colourful rhetoric but very, very little action, by anyone beyond China.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520264474000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18130674', u'in_reply_to': u'113106776', u'id': u'113121218', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'violagirl', u'text': u'Stop subsidizing oil and move to solar and wind. Subsidize the production of electric cars. Help people understand that we are not entitled to eat every fruit and vegetable imaginable every day of the year and move to a diet that is obtainable largely from the area where we live. Minimize meat eating. Walk more in general. Government should carefully evaluate and subsidize emerging technologies that hope to remove carbon from the atmosphere. Stop plastic production as there are other viable things to use. There is so much we could do if collectively we decided quality of life with clean air and water were more important than quantity and, of course, if the governments would get on board.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520447578000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16022008', u'in_reply_to': u'113200470', u'id': u'113234483', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MarkBLR', u'text': u'BQSTART
If we hit 600ppm CO2 by 2100, then we would be on the way to completely melting the polar ice caps, raising the oceans 220ft. Again, the main question is "how fast?". Are we talking, a few hundred years, or tens of thousands of years??? I do not think we know enough about the processes involved to give a firm answer.
BQEND
The last time the IPCC gave a quantitative answer to the "How fast ?" question regarding the Greenland and Antarctic ice-sheets completely melting was in the TAR, way back in 2001 (WG1 report, section 11.5.4.3, pages 677-679).
For Greenland Figure 11.16 shows it taking about 1000 years to melt (Greenland is roughly equivalent to 6 to 7 metres of sea-level rise) at a sustained (local !) temperature of +8°C (roughly equal to a global mean temperature rise of +4°C).
For the WAIS, although they did mention one model that "causes the demise of WAIS ice shelves in a few hundred years and would float a large part of the WAIS (and marine portions of East Antarctica) after 1,000 years", they also wrote :
BQSTART
The potential of WAIS to collapse in response to future climate change is still a subject of debate and controversy.
BQENDThat is still the case today.
For the EAIS they wrote :
BQSTART
East Antarctic ice sheet Thresholds for disintegration of the East Antarctic ice sheet by surface melting involve warmings above 20°C, a situation that has not occurred for at least the last 15 million years (Barker et al., 1999), and which is far more than thought possible under any scenario of climatic change currently under consideration. In that case, the ice sheet would decay over a period of at least 10,000 years.
BQEND
For the entire set of ice-sheets to melt the correct timeframe would appear to be "millenia", though sea-level rise on the order of 5 to 10 metres could occur in the "a few hundred years" range if nothing is done over that period.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520440519000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3985037', u'in_reply_to': u'113201104', u'id': u'113228363', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'loco_p_man', u'text': u'BQSTART
You simply don't have your facts straight
BQEND
Bernie, which fact are you objecting to ? We both agree that the Accord was never submitted for senate ratification, as Obama signed it using his SOE authority. If this could not be treated as such, I am sure that litigious members of the GOP would have challenged it. The fact that none has done so leaves one with little option but to conclude that it was entirely legitimate, no matter how much you dislike it.
Let me remind you : you said that US is not part of the Paris agreement. You were wrong. Get over it.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520263518000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'113117643', u'id': u'113120397', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'I'm glad you agree with yourself. Up till now you've repeatedly shown that you are immune to education. Looking forward to having you report this insult to your ignorance..', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520261545000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'113117379', u'id': u'113118741', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Marie Karim', u'text': u'I wonder how many of the 3% of scientist who deny climate changes are involved with the petro chem (or coal) industry? Or affiliated politically (or financially) with other businesses that environmental savings will damage over the short term', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520430230000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17940248', u'id': u'113218720', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'The current administration began in Jan 2017, though it seems longer. The accumulation of CO2 to the extent that it was bringing about climate changes could be traced back to the industrial revolution. 
When did we find out about global warming? At different points different people became aware of the dangers of the increasing accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere. The Guardian ran an article (not that long ago) about a President's Commission on the subject of fossil fuels and CO2 inaugurated and signed by Lyndon Johnson. Recently a glaciologist named John Mercer was remembered for his work in the field and warnings from 1978. I myself only began to become aware of climatology and its findings fairly recently. I started following the debate around a decade ago.
Tell us who's to blame, you ask. Anyone who suppresses scientific information, defunds studies, and deliberately deflects from scientific reports, shares culpability. The promoters of oil and coal and their lobbyists as well as the paid hacks and bought politicians share the blame fairly equally. "A probabilistic quantification of the anthropogenic component of twentieth century global warming" - Wigley & Santer, 2012.
For forcing by greenhouse gases (GHGs) only, we show that there is a greater than 90 % probability that the expected warming over 1950–2005 is larger than the total amount (not just “most”) of the observed warming.
So other factors don't even need to be included, to account for the recent warming.
"Global temperature evolution 1979–2010" - Foster & Rahmstorf, 2011

...........we list the linear trend in the signals due to ENSO, volcanic forcing and solar variation in table 3. Hence these factors have not contributed to an upward trend in temperature data, rather they have contributed a very slight downward trend.
BQEND
So all the current warming is related to human activity, because the sum of all natural forcings would be cooling the Earth very very slowly now.

Published in Limnology and Oceanography Letters, the results demonstrate that organic carbon from permafrost is making its way into the waters of these regions. This type of carbon is particularly good at absorbing sunlight."

A scientist states that the permafrost holds twice the amount of greenhouse gases than we currently have in our atmosphere.Scientists from the Arctic Council say that all of the permafrost will thaw by 2100 and 20% will thaw by 2040.The Earth if it did not have any greenhouse gases would be too cold to support life. BQSTART

BQEND
How is that a cherry pick, since the conclusion involves an accounting of all known forcings, natural or otherwise?
Since the sum of all known natural forcings are negative, and the sum of all known anthropogenic forcings (and their feedbacks) more than account for observed warming, it is a very simple logical conclusion.
Skeptical science have a good graphic outlining the results of the various attribution studies.
It may be the case that the accounting of forcings is wrong, but that's not what the current body of evidence states.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520250341000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': u'more than all of it'}], u'author_id': u'18495475', u'in_reply_to': u'112950428', u'id': u'113109187', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'I don't think there is any real evidence for the kind of sudden catastrophe implied by '[...] when complex complex systems breakdown there is very limited warning [...]'. We all like to imagine sudden catastrophic changes because they're easy to think about, but in fact I think the system is extremely likely to be robust against that sort of thing. I think that as far as we know it has been broadly robust in the past, for instance: except in the case of really huge disturbances like enormous rocks falling from space. Certainly it seems unlikely that we'd see the kind of life we do if the climate kept falling off cliffs.
On the other hand you could argue that what is happening now is a really large disturbance: certainly the rate of change (which, within limits, is the bad thing) is about ten times higher now than it was during the most recent deglaciation, for instance.
That doesn't mean we're not in big trouble: we are. It also seems plausible to me that there will be large & extremely rapid insults to the climate in the fairly near future: we are supporting a lot of people on quite narrow margins. When the harvests fail in the US there's basically going to be a horde of very hungry zombies, with nuclear weapons: the resulting war will probably have a pretty dramatic & rapid impact on the climate.
 I am quite glad that I will be dead before the worst of it happens & also that I don't have children to feel guilty about.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520362849000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"they 're easy to think about", u'effect': u'to imagine sudden catastrophic changes'}], u'author_id': u'13299353', u'in_reply_to': u'112911028', u'id': u'113187762', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'radio4head', u'text': u'To be fair, I see disagreement among experts on jet stream meanderings. The fast warming of the Arctic matches models, but how the weaker jet stream affects seasonal weather isn't clear. Not everyone agrees with Jennifer Francis about 'cold continents' (although some do). Hot weather records have been outpacing cold weather records, but it's possible that quasi-stationary Rossby waves will result in longer periods of both hot and cold weather.
How weird will it get? Well, Katharine Kayhoe is more qualified than Paul Beckwith (not that they necessarily disagree), and her YouTube channel is called 'Global Weirding'.
On the whole, there are few opportunities to get climate change mentioned in headlines that are dominated by the short term, so I can see why any weather event is used as an opening, even before the possibility of establishing whether they are more likely as a result of global warming.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520360263000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'quasi - stationary rossby waves', u'effect': u'longer periods of both hot and cold weather'}], u'author_id': u'13018309', u'in_reply_to': u'112930227', u'id': u'113186030', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathonFields', u'text': u'China is doing more than any other nation on the planet to mitigate climate Change. Just as the corruption of government in the UK is threatening the continuity of the United Kingdom, and creating Brexshit, so the corrupt Trump administration is threatening the break up of the United States.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520184354000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4634960', u'in_reply_to': u'113060470', u'id': u'113079146', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ArcticDunkey', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQEND
A few million hunter-gatherers being incompatible with mega-fauna is a rather harsh definition of the planet's carrying capacity, e.g. the ability of the Earth to carry humans without severe environmental degradation. I think you would need to be seeing a more widespread failure, like today's.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520249842000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18495475', u'in_reply_to': u'112948723', u'id': u'113108748', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'radio4head', u'text': u'China's contribution to global warming is obviously immense. That doesn't absolve the US, EU or other industrialised countries from urgent action. Nor does it absolve China. Yesterday, Reuters reported that China was well ahead of schedule to 'slash' coal production capacity by 500 Mt/yr from 2016 to 2020. But that still leaves about 3.4 Gt. They're closing 'inefficient' generating capacity, great. But they're still bringing more 'efficient' coal capacity on stream, which I don't think is acceptable. 
"If all the coal-fired power plants that are currently planned were built, the carbon budget for reaching the 2 °C temperature target would nearly be depleted. ... The phase-out of coal requires dedicated and well-designed policies." That paper mentions Turkey, Indonesia, Bangladesh, Pakistan and Egypt as planning more polluting coal, and the Climate Action Tracker says pledges from China, India and Indonesia are not 'consistent with limiting warming below 2 °C as it would require many other countries to make a comparably greater effort and much deeper reductions'.
So how do we help achieve the necessary ambition in industrialising countries? Diplomacy and co-operation, obviously, but also international or bilateral mechanisms? Governments need to invest as well as regulate at many levels. Besides assistance with decarbonising, countries can also impose Border Carbon Adjustments, which should encourage producer countries to align their pricing of fossil fuels appropriately (so that producer nations keep the income rather than the country imposing the duty). Any other suggestions?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520355558000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13018309', u'in_reply_to': u'113069998', u'id': u'113181628', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

description: Dana Nuccitelli: A new study finds that waiting 5 extra years to peak carbon pollution will cost 20 cm sea level rise
headline: i
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: A new study finds that waiting 5 extra years to peak carbon pollution will cost 20 cm sea level rise
og_fields.og:title: Actions today will decide Antarctic ice sheet loss and sea level rise | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
A new study published in Nature looks at how much global sea level will continue to rise even if we manage to meet the Paris climate target of staying below 2°C hotter than pre-industrial temperatures. The issue is that sea levels keep rising for several hundred years after we stabilize temperatures, largely due to the continued melting of ice sheets in Antarctica and Greenland from the heat already in the climate system.
The study considered two scenarios. In the first, human carbon pollution peaks somewhere between 2020 and 2035 and falls quickly thereafter, reaching zero between 2035 and 2055 and staying there. Global temperatures in the first scenario peak at and remain steady below 2°C. In the second scenario, we capture and sequester carbon to reach net negative emissions (more captured than emitted) between 2040 and 2060, resulting in falling global temperatures in the second half of the century.
The authors found that global average sea level will most likely rise by about 1.3 meters by 2300 in the first scenario, and by 1 meter in the second. However, there is large uncertainty due to how little we understand about the stability of the large ice sheets in Greenland and especially Antarctica. At the high end of possible ice sheet loss, we could see as much as 4.5 meters of sea level rise by 2300 in the first scenario, and close to 3 meters in the second scenario.
The study also shows that it’s critical that our carbon pollution peaks soon. Each 5-year delay – a peak in 2025 instead of 2020, for example – most likely adds 20 cm of sea level rise by 2300, and could potentially add a full meter due to the uncertainty associated with the large ice sheets:
we find that a delay of global peak emissions by 5 years in scenarios compatible with the Paris Agreement results in around 20 cm of additional median sea-level rise in 2300 … we estimate that each 5 years of delay bear the risk of an additional 1 m of sea-level rise by 2300 … Delayed near-term mitigation action in the next decades will leave a substantial legacy for long-term sea-level rise.
And remember, this is all for scenarios in which we meet the Paris climate targets, which we’re currently not on pace to achieve. If we miss the Paris targets, sea levels will rise higher yet.
Another new study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, found that sea level rise has been accelerating. If the rate of acceleration continues – which the lead author notes is a conservative estimate – we would see an additional 65 cm (close to a meter above pre-industrial sea level) of sea level rise by 2100.
Yet another new study published in The Cryosphere using satellite data found that while the East Antarctic Ice Sheet has remained stable in recent years, ice loss from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet has accelerated. Antarctica is now discharging 1.93 trillion tons of ice each year, up from about 1.89 trillion tons per year in 2008. When accounting for snow accumulation, the continent is losing about 183 billion tons of ice per year – enough to raise sea levels by about 3 to 5 millimeters per decade by itself. The melting of the Greenland Ice Sheet is likewise accelerating and is now responsible for about 25% of annual sea level rise (8.5 millimeters per decade).
Meanwhile, the Arctic has been remarkably warm in February – as much as 35°C hotter than average in some areas. In mid-winter, when sea ice should be growing, in the Bering Sea it’s instead shrinking. 
Today's Bering Sea ice extent was lower than any value from Jan 15th to May 2nd during any of the previous 38 years; and the Feb 20th value was only half of the previous lowest Feb 20 value. #akwx @AlaskaWx @ZLabe pic.twitter.com/FPXThXkdUC
The hot Arctic is important because the temperature difference between the Arctic and lower latitudes is one of the main forces that keeps the jet stream moving steadily west-to-east. With a hot Arctic, the jet stream is weakened, leading to weird weather in the USA and Europe. As a result, the western states have been experiencing relatively quite cold temperatures, while the US east coast has been unseasonably hot.
To sum up, ice sheet melt is accelerating, as in turn is sea level rise. Even if we manage to achieve the Paris target of less than 2°C global warming above pre-industrial temperatures, we’re likely to eventually see more than a meter of sea level rise, and potentially several meters. The longer we take to reach peak carbon pollution in the coming years, the higher the oceans will rise. Disappearing sea ice in the rapidly-warming Arctic also appears to be causing increasingly weird and extreme weather in places like America and Europe.

As I have pointed out only a few days ago, this is "noise"
It is not statistically relevant.
It is not scientifically relevant.
It makes no difference to the climate trend.
Climate is measured over 30 years, as defined back in 1934 by the IMO (the WMO's predecessor). This is text book knowledge for anyone genuinely interested in climate matters.
As others have pointed out, the genuinely informed were expecting such wilfully ignorant tripe and were taking bets on when it would be posted by the deniers.
Well done, you may have made some people some money for so hastily proclaiming a cooling trend and confirming the statistical and scientific ignorance of deniers writ large.
On top of which as has also been pointed out you are using El Nino peak years to try and prove your point which is why you are doubly wrong because we know the El Nino/La Nina cycles which are internal variables are the reason the 30 years period was chosen. Again textbook knowledge dating back to the 1960's and earlier.
Comical.
All the best.', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520099353000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we know', u'effect': u'as has also been pointed out you are using el nino peak years to try and prove your point which is why you are doubly wrong'}], u'author_id': u'3917113', u'in_reply_to': u'113003763', u'id': u'113035811', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'So given your personal epistemological method, what do you believe when billionaires tell you that AGW is NOT happening, as they not infrequently do (Trump, Kochs, etc.)?Does that mean you then believe AGW IS happening, because science is chiefly judged according to the inverse of the opinions of laypeople with a lot of money, or do you actually not really bother consistantly thinking any of this through at all?', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520158692000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'science is chiefly judged according to the inverse of the opinions of laypeople with a lot of money or do you actually not really bother consistantly thinking any of this through at all', u'effect': u'when billionaires tell you that agw is not happening trump you then believe agw is happening'}], u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'113042689', u'id': u'113059883', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'If the cost for polluting the atmosphere was not off balance sheet fossil fuel use would be very expensive. Fossil fuels are valuable chemical feedstocks - burning them is stupid. As for paying taxes in Switzerland - why is it that a lot of bankers live there? Low taxes.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520158186000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17327071', u'in_reply_to': u'113027074', u'id': u'113059501', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'We always knew "No warming since 1998" would be replaced by "No warming since 2016" because misinterpreting the temperature records is part of the usual pattern in these discussions.
So-called climate sceptics have only one plan - to confuse people.
They provide a selection of conflicting ideas, along these lines:
When considering global temperature rise, declining sea ice area, melting glaciers, or sea level rise .........
(a) it is not happening and
(b) it is a natural event and
(c) it is a good thing
All at the same time, or one at a time, as required.
Some say "Temperatures havn't changed for ...... years." (With various different numbers in the gap.)
Others say "The Earth has been cooling for ..... years." (As above)
Some say "It's the Sun causing the warming." (solar scientists don't agree).
Others say "It's all a hoax".
Or "It's a religion".
Others say "There's an Ice Age coming".
Or "It's all caused by volcanoes."
And so on and so on.
Some say there is no such thing as a greenhouse effect (there is), others say the rise in CO2 is natural (it isn't).
When one of them posts any one of the above ideas, strangely the others (who have posted different ideas just before) don't pile in and argue with them.
They only argue with people posting material based on scientific research.
It's a fringe view, based on no evidence.
They appear to be just another group of conspiracy theorists - but of course some are linked to various vested interests.
These folk are only sceptical of things from actual scientific sources, never from stuff produced by fringe eccentrics, who they believe no matter how confused and contradictory that material might be.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520099230000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'misinterpreting the temperature records is part of the usual pattern in these discussions', u'effect': u'no warming since 1998 would be replaced by no warming'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the warming'}, {u'cause': u'volcanoes', u'effect': u'it'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'113025709', u'id': u'113035750', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'BQSTART
This wouldn't have anything to do with the inconvenient fact that global temperatures have been in a tailspin since 2016, would it?
BQEND
Oh, as expected - you want to compare an El Nino event with the period straight after an El Nino event.
However, every La Nina year since 1998 has been warmer than every El Nino year before 1995.
To date, all 17 years of the 21st century rank among the 18 warmest on record (adding 1998 makes up the full 18.)
The top 5 years (from NOAA) are - 5th, 2010 ....... 4th, 2014 .... 3rd, 2017 ...... 2nd, 2015 .... 1st, 2016.
The ENSO cycle is the most significant short-term cycle; it contributes some of the "wiggle" in the trend.
I don't often post a video, but this one produced by a scientist illustrates the concept:

The variation in human characteristics is determined by the environments we create for ourselves.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520103156000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2578129', u'in_reply_to': u'113015982', u'id': u'113037403', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'A valid point - these events do happen from time to time.
Patterns and trends are the significant things.
I've got an atlas from 1989 which includes climate maps for the UK.
For the 30-year period 1951-1980, it shows central England with an average of 10 to 20 mornings with snow cover per year.
NOW in central England, we don't get an average of 10 to 20 mornings with snow cover per year any more, because central England is warmer.
However, this particular winter we've had a lot of snow mornings, above the current average.
The part of the article that really matters is the odd state of affairs in the Arctic.

To investigate the role of feedback mechanisms Pithan and Maritsen employ an inverted radiative kernel methodology and devise a linear decomposition of the individual contributions to tropical and Arctic warming (Fig. 1). Also Planck feedback makes a sizeable contribution to Arctic amplification, such that together these two temperature feedbacks dominate the response.
BQEND my bold.
The overal science on Planck feedback-
BQSTART
the Planck feedback: The higher the temperature of a radiating body, the more energy it radiates. This is a negative feedback, and it is very strong, so the total feedback is negative for our Earth. In climate science, the Planck feedback is often not mentioned and explained explicitly.
BQEND
i.e. A feedback that reduces an initial warming is a "negative feedback.", yet the study you refer to suggests that it may have greater role in Arctic amplified warming and hence a positive feedback.

description: Editorial: When does weather turn into climate? The cold snap in Britain and Europe may be a sign of really dangerous change elsewhere
og_fields.og:description: Editorial: When does weather turn into climate? The cold snap in Britain and Europe may be a sign of really dangerous change elsewhere
og_fields.og:title: The Guardian view on snow and ice: it’s too cold here but too warm in the Arctic | Editorial
text:
The weather is extremely worrying. It has never been so warm for so long at this time of year before and it is just possible that the effects will be catastrophic. We are talking, of course, about the Arctic, where over vast areas of frozen sea the temperatures are higher than they are in Britain today. A blast of winter in Britain and across much of northern Europe is unpleasant but perfectly survivable and affects few people outside the region, but a period of unseasonal warming in the Arctic could be the harbinger of something that changes the whole world for the worse. Both could be connected so that the cold winds that belong in the Arctic have broken out southwards to chill us while warm winds melt the ice cap. We don’t know, but that’s no reason for complacency.
Precisely because climate change on the scale now under way is outside all previous experience of which we have records, it’s impossible to know which unprecedented fluctuations are those that mark the transition to a new and more dangerous state. That determination can only be made long afterwards, when it is too late to change anything. It does not mean there is nothing to worry about; only that we can’t be certain what ought to worry us. This one probably should. The weather in the Arctic has always shifted dramatically over short periods, but the drama has never been this intense since records began. At one spot in Greenland the temperature rose 36C above the annual average, and for two days in February the north pole has been warmer than Zurich in Switzerland.
The system of global climate is extremely complicated and full of feedback loops that are not properly understood, but the worry is that the freak warming of the Arctic marks the emergence of a new feedback loop where increasing temperature leads to still more destabilising rises. The polar vortex, a great girdle of winds that keeps the cold air of the Arctic separate from the warmer air of temperate regions, seems to be weakening. Warm air goes north; cold air comes south. In the long run, everything grows warmer.
At the moment, this seems to be mainly affecting the Arctic sea ice, which is shrinking at an astonishing rate but does not of itself contribute to rising sea levels. The fear must be that the great ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica, which rest on buried land, will melt and drown many of the world’s most populated coastlines. Sea levels will rise for the rest of this century even if the ambitious targets of the Paris accords are met. These commit the world to cutting the net emissions of greenhouse gases to zero by 2050. Even if that happens, the latest research suggests that sea levels will continue to rise for another two centuries, and may do so by a completely catastrophic amount. The change in behaviour must come quickly: every five years’ delay in action may add another 20cm to the projected sea level rise.
All these changes may seem small and distant. It is human nature to worry more about 2cm of snow falling in our back yard today than all the oceans of the world rising by 10 times as much over the next century. But the one is a parochial inconvenience and the other a global catastrophe. The snow this week may be a warning of something very much more destructive and we should act as if it were, even if we can’t be certain that it is. The consequences of misplaced optimism would be far worse than those of a pessimism that was not borne out by events. Our descendants won’t thank us if they never see any snow in a shrunken Britain where the coastline runs past Cambridge.

Kilgore', u'text': u'This article does not mention the effect of particulate matter of woodsmoke on people with C.O.P.D. and/or asthma.
Let us have a moment of silence for the nursing staff on the UK's pulmonary wards during this current crisis.Ii have come on duty at such times as this when the smell of smoke in the hospital's parking lot made one think of the great london fire. 
I wonder if the people coming on duty are also greeted with, "Welcome to hell" and, "I hope you ate yer wheaties, Pal."', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519957097000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314107', u'id': u'112947774', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Continentalcyclist', u'text': u'I am aware of the use of heat pumps. They have an important part to play. And they do in this country. As does thermal and PV solar.
But heat pumps are only one element of the future. They require vast amounts of electricity throughout the winter cycle. Even a minergy standard home, of which there are virtually none in Britain, will require 3000 kWh per heating season. Or 20 kWh per day on an average winter day. Or 30 kWh on a cold day. When the grid is creaking. By comparison our entire domestic electricity consumption per year is 1800 kWh. And many homes here produce more eletricity than they use.
Presumable, in addition to the mass use of heat pumps, you also want electrical cars. How are you going to cope?
Your claims on emissions are wrong. For one thing carbon monoxiode is highly toxic, but not a greenhouse gas. Carbon dioxide is. It is the result of incomplete combustion. State-of-the-art wood burning does not produce methane. Methane emissions are also the result of incomplete combustion, ie incomplete chemical reduction because of insufficient temperatures and oxygen input. 
You need to check your chemistry. If you knew German I would refer you to the association of Swiss oven builders and their computer modulations requisite for every single oven installed.
The same holds for black carbon. It is fuel emitted unburnt.
You refer to 'domestic heaters’. Again you are unaware of the technologies developed in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and elsewhere. We do not use Villagers or Agas.
There is no single fix to the energy and climate future. In the building sector heat pumps are one very important element. But they require an awful lot of electrical power, in winter, when it is least available. I have a fairly good grasp on the capacities of the Alpine storage batteries in winter and know their limitations, as well as the limitations of the grid in Continental Europe. In Britain the situation is much worse. Without interconnectors to the Continent, Norway and Ireland, the UK cannot install sufficient heat pump capacity. Particularly as long as it still exports waste to Oslo (of all places) to heat the homes in Norway, in combination with electricity generation and steam for industries. With plenty of oil, gas, and hydro electricity available.
We are far ahead of the UK in combined heating systems in cities, from waste burning, sewage treatment plants, geothermal, and waste heat from industries, office servers and cooling systems. And wood there plays a part, as woodchips, pellets, and logs. Whereas Britain still does landfills, with huge amounts of uncaptured methane emissions. They are extremely potent climate agents.
In new homes we need no outside heating input at all. Solar with a one hundred cubic metre boiler will do.
But the real crunch is the combustion engine, road transport. Urban transit systems, trains, trams, trolleybuses on renewable electricity, cycling, walking, planning reducing commuter distances: that is where the music plays. And air transport. Why airline kerosene is untaxed is difficult to convey.
Tunnel vision will not do. Check your science, check your energy computations, look at the entire picture, and then come back.
Or build one hundred nuclear power plants in the UK. Within the next five to ten years. Just how? Is that your agenda?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520148428000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'insufficient temperatures and oxygen input', u'effect': u'methane emissions are also the result of incomplete combustion ie incomplete chemical reduction'}], u'author_id': u'11797417', u'in_reply_to': u'113053993', u'id': u'113054778', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EnviroSci', u'text': u'Wood stoves produce black carbon, methane and carbon monoxide, all of which are very powerful greenhouse pollutants that cause a lot more global warming than the CO2 from the stove. Over the next 20 years (the critical period if we are to achieve the target set at Paris of keeping global warming well below 2 degrees), heating a house with a wood stove will cause more global warming than a dozen similar houses heated by modern, efficient, electric heat pumps (also called reverse cycle air conditioners).
This means that burning wood in domestic heaters can never be climate-friendly any more than a simple 30,000 volt electrode can clean up more that a fraction of the pollution from the average wood stove.
Modern, efficient heat pumps have superseded wood stoves and natural gas as the most cost-effective climate-friendly heating. The most efficient model can deliver 5 times as much heat to the home as it uses in electric power, even when the outside temperature is 5 degrees below freezing. They are affordable (as cheap as buying a wood stove) and have lower running costs than buying firewood and in addition to causing only a tiny fraction of the global warming, they don't damage our health. For a detailed analysis, see woodsmoke 3sc net/ghg (replace spaces with dots).', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520144509000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'a lot more global warming than the co2'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'more global warming than a dozen similar houses heated by modern pumps'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'only a tiny fraction of the global warming'}], u'author_id': u'4386683', u'in_reply_to': u'113042841', u'id': u'113053993', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'You might win that one.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519956745000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'112947627', u'id': u'112947690', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shanesw', u'text': u'50 bucks says you end up with relatively S.F.A up-votes for that outstanding comment; it's far too relevant.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519956468000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17473764', u'in_reply_to': u'112946497', u'id': u'112947627', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ScottishScientist1', u'text': u'BQSTART

I'm slack-jawed incredulous that someone claiming to be a scientist can make such a moronic statement as this:- 
"...wild rain-forests and other wet-lands would lock less carbon than the same wet-lands dedicated to biomass production..."
You obviously know very little about mono-culture biomass production..
BQENDThat's still not "a point" but you may have given me a clue as to your misunderstanding.
The carbon amounts I am comparing are the one hand
1. "I would assume that wild rain-forests and other wet-lands would lock less carbon"That is to say, the carbon locked by the wild wet-land.
with
2. "the same wet-lands dedicated to biomass production can substitute for fossil fuels leaving more carbon fossilised net".That is to say, the carbon harvested from the biomass but NOT, as you may have misunderstood me, "the carbon locked on the biomass production farm" which I am happy to assume to be ZERO carbon.
I am comparing wild wetland sequestration of carbon with cultivated wetland exported produced carbon.
It is the produced carbon that is of interest because that exported and burned in a power station carbon can substitute one for one for carbon in fossil fuel that can stay underground and never be extracted.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520127594000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that exported and burned in a power station carbon', u'effect': u'that is of interest'}], u'author_id': u'14857627', u'in_reply_to': u'113002858', u'id': u'113050426', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Continentalcyclist', u'text': u'"Burning wood releases more CO2 than gas, oil and even coal for the same amount of heat, so to make it climate neutral we need an increase in forests"
"It seems that wood burning is not climate neutral in the short term and requires an increase in forested area to be climate neutral in the longer term."
Some serious thinking is required here. And scientific analysis. 
In sustainable forestry, with as much wood growing as is used for heating, the carbon balance over one year is neutral. And incidentally dead wood rotting will release the same amount of carbon as will wood used for heating, unless it is buried and sealed in the ground, turning to peat and eventually coal under water in moors. 
Sustainable forestry prevails across the European Alps. In fact more wood grows (and eventually decomposes unless used) than is harvested. Heating with woodchips and pellets therefore makes sense. And so do log fires with state-of-the-art burning facilities ensuring high temperatures and a sufficient oxygen supply to ensure a complete chemical reduction. 
Any burning of coal and oil will release all the carbon extracted from the earth into the atmosphere, and even supposedly environment friendly gas contains considerable amounts of carbon which is released as carbon dioxide upon burning.
In sustainable forestry the very same amount of carbon dioxide is released by burning or rotting as is split up into carbon and oxygen and thus turned into wood by photosynthesis in the same annual cycle, reducing the carbon dioxide to carbon and oxygen. It is hence carbon neutral. And has been for millenia. In fact since the last ice age. When forests began to grow.
So, given sustainable forestry, with the same amount of wood growing as is used, heating with wood will be carbon neutral. Coal, oil and gas will not.
Our area has the highest amount of timber per hectare of forest in Europe: 400 cubic metres. It also has a lot of biodiversity, with a mix of many kinds of trees, as well as a mix of old and young trees side by side. The maximum amount of trees foresters are allowed to cut in any area is defined by the height of the trees. With trees measuring a length of 25 m, a circle of at the most 50 m diametres may be cut. But mostly individual trees will be taken out, providing space and light for the others and for saplings to grow naturally. Called ungleich verjüngter Blenterwald.
In many areas chimneys are equipped with filtres. Our chimney has a steel tube with a 30,000 Volt DC electrode magnetising any unburnt soot particles, which will then settle on the steel tube, where the chimney sweep will vacuum them up.
The claims made by the article are unsustainable. They only apply if forests are cut down wholesale, as they will be for cattle grazing or soy bean production, or for coconut palms. Instead of castigating wood burners, the authors might have pointed out the effects of meat production in Brazil. Or beef, pork or chicken production and consumption in our parts, with soy beans used as fodder.
Burning wood alongside sustainable forestry is climate friendly. The statement above to the contrary else is untenable. Eat less meat if you wish to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. In the process you will also lower methane emissions by cattle. And methane is a far for potent climate gas than carbon dioxide.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520114213000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11797417', u'id': u'113042841', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'djw300', u'text': u'I'm astounded that after years of trying to clean the environment and banning domestic fires, wood burning heaters have been allowed to become popular. The pollution they throw out is significant, not only for those in and around them in the home, but also to anybody who lives nearby.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519955724000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2947349', u'id': u'112947446', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Guess what's causing increased extreme weather events [electrical storms], yep AGW. Guess whats causing AGW, clues in the name A= anthropogenic.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519954813000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'what', u'effect': u'increased extreme weather events storms'}, {u'cause': u'what', u'effect': u'agw'}], u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112944685', u'id': u'112947215', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GKB507', u'text': u'..all for 30,000* direct jobs and yet more oil to flood global markets.* https://davidsuzuki.org/story/cant-close-eyes-climate-change/', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520101749000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11145063', u'in_reply_to': u'113032889', u'id': u'113036838', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'When people talk about 'terrible accidents like Fukushuma' it is important to ask the following question: who died or will die as a result of Fukushima, and what was the cause of their deaths? How do these numbers compare to the number of deaths from the event which caused the accident?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520098953000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'the accident'}], u'author_id': u'13299353', u'in_reply_to': u'113028061', u'id': u'113035616', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'I can't fault anything you've said. The only issue is their are over 70 million people in the UK. Burning wood as a sustainable way to move forward just isnt feasible.
Nearly all woodland in the UK isnt managed anything like you've described.
Nearly all the wood burnt in the UK probably doesn't even come from the UK.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519953424000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112946627', u'id': u'112946846', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DBluge', u'text': u'It's only possible to burn wood ecologically if you are doing it as part of a managed system. If you harvest from a large enough area, and know the limits, it's easily possible to 'grow' more carbon than you burn. The yield is variable, obviously, depending on tree types and terrain.
Many hardwood forests in S.E. Ontario are woefully mismanaged as woodlots. You can tell this from the size of the logs generally harvested for firewood. It's not uncommon for people to destroy the unwanted smaller trees in order to pull out the big stuff.
With 'selective thinning' you'll see stretch marks on the remaining trees after only a few years - as growth accelerates, the canopy is opened up, and competition is removed. You hardly ever need to cut big healthy trees. Dead and dying trees are often dangerous to cut and are such a wonderful wildlife resource that they are best left. Intelligently harvested firewood consists mostly of smaller dia. trees. The best trees are grown on and individually harvested at maturity for fine furniture etc. Firewood should only be a small part of the overall harvest. Of course as you go back and rework an area (always with the same philosophy) the thinnings you harvest are inevitably of increased size. It's essentially just horticulture - on a larger scale. As we've only just begun to understand the symbiotic complexities of what's going on under the forest floor, whatever we do in terms of harvest should be done with a very high degree of humility. If you're not tearing up the forest with heavy machinery and ATV's it's almost impossible to see where you've been working after six months or so. After five or six years the growth on the remaining trees can be quite remarkable.
A wood stove should only be considered as part of an equation. Buying and burning wood in a city, outside of that equation, makes absolutely no sense. English woodlands flourished for centuries while supporting a whole raft of different crafts. Trees were often selected decades in advance for particular uses and cultivated accordingly. Semi-industrialised mass clear cutting for ship building and steel making was the death knell for many areas. Excepting that, local people, intimately familiar with their locality, knew pretty precisely just how much they could sustainably harvest. You never clear-cut an area. You go out of your way to preserve the ground cover. You never open up areas to erosion. You avoid the temptation to clean up too much. Brash piles make great temporary habitat for wildlife and seedlings.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519952712000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4390585', u'id': u'112946627', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KeepShtum', u'text': u'Watch in awe as the Tories silently realise biomass at Drax was a huge and costly mistake and then attempt to 'relax' emissions regulations.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520098671000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3175271', u'id': u'113035467', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Trees are part of short term carbon cycles so burning them is not as disruptive to long term carbon cycles as the burning of fossil fuels.
We're burning fossil fuels one million times faster than nature replenishes them which is warming the planet dangerously fast.
But burning trees doesn't help, for example Northern Boreal forest wildfires, which have been increasing due to increased heat, drought, pests and reduced snow cover, have been dumping ash on the Greenland Ice Sheet, increasing heat retention and melt rate.
And the burning of the Amazon to make way for human activity is disrupting atmospheric rivers of moisture heading to mega-cities like Sao Paulo.
If the Amazon goes up in smoke, as one paper I read about suggested was a possibility at a temperature of 3 degrees C above pre-industrial, it could release enough carbon to push us well into a 4 degree world.', u'recommendation_count': u'14', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519952289000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'increased heat drought', u'effect': u'which have been increasing'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'112946497', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GKB507', u'text': u'Part of the tragedy of the Canadian tar sands is that in addition to contributing 9.8% of Canada's CO2 emissions, it also wastes the natural gas that so many of us rely on for electricity and heating our houses.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520093877000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11145063', u'id': u'113032889', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mary1952', u'text': u'Julian, my truly awful wood burning (and rubbish burning) neighbours were in a town where wood burning was permitted. They had the latest high spec. stove, complied with chimney height and regs. & were delighted with it. Inside their home (my husband went in once ...) it was like a smoky cave - but they seemed to be fine there - apart from their constant runny noses, raspy voices & white-faced grandchildren at the windows. They had their own wood lot and a smelly diesel truck to bring their logs home in. Initially, we said "live and let live" and out up with it despite beginning to feel very poorly. After a few years (we stayed there too long) we were desperate to go. But maybe those people just have (had) stronger lungs? With all respect, where you say "it doesn't mean it shouldn't be done", I have to disagree - because how could a local authority say some people may burn wood and yet others may not? If you mean that some may live in far off remote places where wood is their only option, well, I see your point - but even then there's propane gas and maybe heat pump and solar options? I suppose if someone can truly exist well away from the possibility of polluting the air their neighbours ahve to breathe, if they are not damaging the health of their own children, or visitors, then it MIGHT be up to them - whether or not to run a wood stove - supplied by a properly sustained wood lot. But how many people can live like that today, honestly not a lot ..... especailly not in towns, or even in village streets. It feels very mediaeval to me - I think it is time to move on ..... otherwise the smoke in the air over us will become far too much - too many stoves have gone in already. But that is only my opinion, I know. I have the time to see this from a distance now.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520093290000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18404292', u'in_reply_to': u'112991928', u'id': u'113032528', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Well no i don't believe it is fine, but i was just making the point its not sustainable.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519951970000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112945662', u'id': u'112946411', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'What has any of that have to do with the environmental impact of burning wood?

To be so, energy released by burning wood, would have to be less than half the equivalent fossil energy minus a further correction for the amount of vegetation from which that mass of fossil fuel originally stemmed.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519950310000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'lower net carbon emissions'}], u'author_id': u'12447100', u'id': u'112945828', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'Are you serious, or taking the piss? I grow willow and every 4 or 5 years coppice the trees. I cut them when green in the spring and by the end of autumn they are dry and ready to burn. They don't emit an ounce of smoke and my woodburner burns all particulates. Only minute amounts escape into the environment. My wood source is sutainable and local. Burning wood is carbon neutral unlike burning fosil fuels which give off carbon which was gathered hundreds of years ago.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519950187000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3129531', u'id': u'112945771', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'cgsac1', u'text': u'In the UK wood burning actually contributes to the environment, it contributes one of the few incomes to forestry in the UK's rural communities at a time when agriculture faces significant uncertainty, In many woodlands, the trees are harvested and managed to ensure wood supply and actually increase forest cover as it means there will be a requirement for trees in the future. Plus many wood burners use storm fallen trees and tree surgery...in the UK if more people used wood burning outside cities it can be environment positive and support sustainable jobs at the grassroots level - compare that to open cast coal mining and there is no comparison', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519949949000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14908983', u'id': u'112945689', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'Exactly: all I was stating was that there is the possibility, while there is (essentially) no possibility for fossil-fuel burning to be carbon-neutral.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520080727000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13299353', u'in_reply_to': u'112977473', u'id': u'113024895', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shanesw', u'text': u'Exactly. Wood burning is fine in a negligibly small number of cases and cannot be scaled up.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519949877000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17473764', u'in_reply_to': u'112944942', u'id': u'112945662', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shanesw', u'text': u'Mate, you need to provide a reference for that elephant.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519949824000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17473764', u'in_reply_to': u'112945587', u'id': u'112945649', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'brian1w', u'text': u'We are aware that 90% of the current UK biomass burning requires feedstock imported thousands of miles mainly from Canada involving 34 day sea journeys using bulk carriers burning heavy oil. Reports detail 25-30% of energy content used in pelleting process and 48% of energy content lost before the timber reaches UK power stations such as Drax where the majority of the energy produced is deliberately wasted in cooling towers. Check specs for dedicated biomass power stations and they display typical hazardous pollution in the emissions at least 30 times higher than equivalent gas per unit of useful power out. The feedstock hazard can vary widely with a 20 times variation in nitrogen content exacerbating NOX creation and operators claiming capability to burn timber with 60% moisture content and including bark which exacerbates deadly air pollution especially locally when aware of emissions inversion characteristics.
 Typical domestic wood burners produce deadly PM2.5 levels many times higher than burning equivalent gas or oil, with reports that the UK is currently adding 200,000 additional wood burners each year confirming deliberate degradation of air quality equating to millions of diesel vehicles. The local problem became obvious this week with the snow displaying soot pollution from wood burners immediately upwind.
 Very few wood burning installations appear to conform with current regulations resulting in avoidable health and environmental impact. Local Authorities are using public cash to assist installation of wood burning at schools and hospitals when aware local air quality degradation equates to thousands of additional diesel vehicles operating locally. It is surely time for the application of a little joined up thinking, due diligence and duty of care in order to help protect the air that we breathe. Rgds Brian Wilson', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520069368000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'avoidable health and environmental impact'}], u'author_id': u'4015161', u'id': u'113015445', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GuyWarren', u'text': u'I said that Carbon Monoxide is a much weaker GHG, and I got it from ghgonline.com, and at less than 100 ppb, it is less than 4,000 times as concentrated as CO2.
And BC is only a warming agent when it lands on surface with a higher albedo reflectance, like snow. In other regions of the planet it is assumed to be a negative forcing factor (Conny & Slater, 2000).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520067741000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13408113', u'in_reply_to': u'113007324', u'id': u'113014126', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Meat Claw', u'text': u'Meat/dairy animal agriculture is the leading cause for global warming. Over the last few days wind power in the UK was running at record levels, imports over interconnectors were run at near maximum levels, coal power stations were running flat out but our normal "base load" from gas was turned right down. It turned out that we were at risk of running out of gas so our "base source" became less than dependable. If we had had two or three times as much wind capacity and more interconnectors we would have had a more robust system. We need to speed up the switch to renewables and the development of a Europe wide supergrid.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520050198000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3382782', u'in_reply_to': u'112941538', u'id': u'113009134', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EnviroSci', u'text': u'The California Air Resources Board, the US EPA and Wikipedia disagree. The latter reports a 20-year Global Warming Potential of 4,470 for black carbon (BC). CARB uses a value of 3,200.
A US EPA report explains what current levels of CO2, methane (CH4) and BC are doing to the climate. CO2 is causing an additional 1.68 W/m2 of warming, methane causes 0.97 and BC 0.88. Sulphur dioxide aerosols reflect sunlight but black carbon increases warming, with a double whammy if it lands on glaciers or polar ice. 
As for carbon monoxide, its 20-year GWP is 18.9 according to the latest IPCC report, so your claim about CO being weaker that CO2 is completely and utterly false. Are you getting your information from the wood stove industry? Vested interests usually distort the truth. For many years the tobacco industry tried to tell us that 'lite cigarettes' were healthy.
Similarly, the wood heating industry tells us that the wood would rot if not burned. Yet most fallen trees decay in open air and don't produce methane. A recent scientific study 'Methane emissions from trees' found that living trees emit more methane than decaying ones! To quote the researchers: "When a tree falls over, it's still functionally the same in terms of methane emissions. Over time, as it decays, my theory is that it gets colonized by soil bacteria that consume methane and it shifts to behave more like the soil, resulting in a methane sink," said Warner.
It's really sad that fake facts produced by vested interests have more influence than real information. The truth is that, as a New Scientist review concluded in January 2017: 'Log-burning stoves are harming our health and speeding up global warming' facebook com/newscientist/videos/10155097669589589/ (replace space with dot).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520036183000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'co2', u'effect': u'an additional 1.68 w m2 of warming'}, {u'cause': u'methane', u'effect': u'0.97 and bc 0.88'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'a methane sink'}], u'author_id': u'4386683', u'in_reply_to': u'112967082', u'id': u'113007324', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walrave', u'text': u'Burning wood most certainly adds CO2 to the atmosphere. Whether it adds more than would be the case if it weren't burnt depends on land use and the degree of decay the wood would have undergone. On a low key sustainable level things even out. At the other end of the spectrum the fires on Borneo are releasing vast, vast quantities of CO2. It's not as simple as saying, it's wood so it's carbon neutral. If it wasn't harvested in a sustainable way or was grown in land where ordinarily forests would have been capturing a lot of carbon than it's adding CO2 to the atmosphere, possibly more so than burning coal for the same amount of heat.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519949498000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12071235', u'in_reply_to': u'112940806', u'id': u'112945518', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RobertBleeker', u'text': u'BQSTART

As for sources of wood, there's still a surprising amount of common land where gathering small amounts of wood is part of the commons. And there's a lot of local log suppliers around the country that manage their own woodland sustainably as the source.
