article_tags: [Trees and forests, Amazon rainforest, Climate change, Wildlife, Biodiversity, Conservation, Environment, World news, WWF]
description: From the Amazon to Africa, WWF report predicts catastrophic losses of as much as 60% of plants and 50% of animals by the end of the century
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: From the Amazon to Africa, WWF report predicts catastrophic losses of as much as 60% of plants and 50% of animals by the end of the century
og_fields.og:title: World’s great forests could lose half of all wildlife as planet warms – report
text:
The world’s greatest forests could lose more than half of their plant species by the end of the century unless nations ramp up efforts to tackle climate change, according to a new report on the impacts of global warming on biodiversity hotspots.
Mammals, amphibians, reptiles and birds are also likely to disappear on a catastrophic scale in the Amazon and other naturally rich ecosysterms in Africa, Asia, North America and Australia if temperatures rise by more than 1.5C, concludes the study by WWF, the University of East Anglia and the James Cook University.
The research in the journal Climate Change examined the impact of three different levels of warming – 2C (the upper target in the 2015 Paris agreement), 3.2C (the likely rise given existing national commitments) and 4.5C (the forecast outcome if emissions trends remain unchanged) on nearly 80,000 plant and animal species in 35 of the world’s most biodiverse regions.
If governments fail to set more ambitious commitments than those currently on the table, the report projects devastating losses of more than 60% of plant species and almost 50% of animal species in the Amazon at a temperature rise of 3.2C. 
If countries lift their efforts sufficiently to reach the 2C goal, the outlook is improved – but still grim – with more than 35% of species at risk of local extinction in the region. If no actions are taken, the picture is apocalyptic, with a likely loss of more than 70% of plant and reptile species and a more than 60% decline of mammal, reptile and bird species in the Amazon.
The picture was similarly alarming in the two other worst affected areas – south-west Australia and the Miombo woodlands in Africa. But nowhere among the selected 35 hotspots escaped massive losses of wildlife, which would have a dire knock-on effect on human society and wellbeing.
The authors considered how warmer weather and wilder rainfall patterns (more droughts and storms) could negatively affect savannas in Africa, jungles in Bangladesh, the Cerrado-Pantanal in Brazil, the Yangtze delta and coastlines in Europe, Madagascar and the Caribbean. It noted how this would create tensions over water between humans and animals, for example African elephants, which drink as much as 250 litres (50 gallons) a day. Sea-level rises would also be devastating for many species, such as tigers in the Sundarbans, which would see 96% of breeding grounds submerged.
The losses might even be higher because the disappearance of one species - such as a tree - can have a knock-on effect on other ecosystems. Fewer plants can also means less rain, according to other recent studies on the role played by the Amazon. More pressing risks – such as habitat loss from land clearance and pollution – were not accounted for.
William Laurance, director of the Centre for Tropical Environmental and Sustainability Science, said: “For the Amazon and Guianas, the WWF report is scary as hell. The loss of half or more of the region’s stunning plant diversity would be a biological blow of almost unimaginable severity.
“However, such computer models with all their assumptions and complexities are really ‘scientific cartoons’ giving us only a rough sketch of the future. But even if they’re only half right, these are very frightening cartoons indeed.”
The study considered two main ways to reduce these losses: adaptation (helping species to migrate to new territories) and mitigation (cutting greenhouse gases more aggressively). The former produced modest improvements thanks to the creation of eco-corridors between protected areas, but this was little help to slow-moving or almost stationary groups, such as orchids, plants, amphibians and reptiles. WWF said there may be a need to translocate such species, which would otherwise be outrun by the pace of climate change.
A partial solution may be relocation. Some animals, such as wolves, have been successfully reintroduced to their former ranges. A paper published today by the Royal identified 130 areas across the globe that might be suitable for carnivore reintroduction and concluded that rewilding will be essential for conservation in the future.
Far better, the authors say, is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to keep warming as close to 1.5C as possible.
“The numbers are a bit of a wake-up call,” said Stephen Cornelius, chief adviser to WWF on climate issues. “If there is one message it is that mitigation makes a big difference. But even that is not enough for a lot of species ... What will be the new normal in coming decades is not something that wildlife has seen before.”
Experts on Amazon wildlife said the findings were alarming, though they noted that such projections are a rough guide to the future.
 Last month, a separate study predicted an ecological tipping point if 25% of the Amazon is deforested, which would cause droughts and environmental degradation over a wider area. The authors argue the 2014-15 drought in São Paulo is a precursor to what may come unless deforestation is halted and more trees are planted. While this is contentious and relates to the size of the forest rather than the number of species, it highlights the wider impacts of a diminished Amazon, which would apply to a different extent with the weakening of forests in other countries.
 Many species are already at risk from other factors, such as habitat destruction, invasive rivals and disease. Climate change adds to those pressures, prompting fears that a sixth mass extinction is already underway.

[{u'author': u'EthanolEurope', u'text': u'Except that your simplistic descriptions are way off. A field produces a crop that can be used in any of many different markets. If an ethanol plant purchases that crop, it does not "burn" the crop, but rather removes the least valuable component of the crop (starch) leaving the fat and protein (and adding protein from spent yeast) for feed and food markets. The world is long on starch and short on fat and protein. Plastering farmland with solar panels presents a trade-off (food vs. energy) whereas the way ethanol actually works in the real world, biofuels ensure more food and more fuel. Naturally, the way the industry works could change, and folks can come up with lots of viable scenarios for why that synergy could break down, but at present there is synergy and not a trade off for anyone interested in looking at the actual data over the past decade.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521653283000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100074623', u'in_reply_to': u'113758564', u'id': u'113848413', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'b_lunt_ma_n', u'text': u'I was thinking more of land use. “partly because the soil is thin and would require enormous inputs”
BQENDPerhaps the key value of the great rainforests is the biodiversity they support. As you point out, they actually are not great at generating topsoil, and so well-managed agriculture could actually increase the fixing of CO2 in accumulating soils. When my wife was studying for her u/g degree, it was being suggested that the Amazon (and other tropical rainforests) were the “lungs of the Earth”, or similarly emotive nonsense - sorry I have limited patience for Biology when it indulges in philosophical narrative and strays away from science. Subsequently, as fashions changed, savannah and temperate grasslands were considered to be more important, as were the tremendous soil-creating capacity of temperate forests.
If we maintain the diversity, but manage agriculture so as to protect and enhance the thin soils, it may be that a better overall outcome could be achieved than simply leaving the rainforest to its own devices.
As an aside, it appears that there may be a perhaps 20,000 year cycle of greening and desertification of the Sahara. I wonder if South America is subject to a similar pattern, or if the Amazon rainforest is a relatively permanent feature of the current layout of continents.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521457515000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'partly the soil is thin and would require enormous inputs', u'effect': u'the key value of the great rainforests is the biodiversity they support'}], u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'113733808', u'id': u'113740511', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'So in practice, largely nuclear. Clearly paradigms other than “absolutely don’t touch” are possible.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521287406000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'113666993', u'id': u'113667677', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EthanolEurope', u'text': u'Dr. Field posits a dichotomy between corn ethanol and switchgrass ethanol. This dichotomy is based on a supposed difference between the two that appears from application of a life cycle analysis. No doubt, Dr. Field has run such an analysis based on data that he has collected somehow and from someplace.
We (i) run the largest ethanol plant in Europe, processing corn, and (ii) we tried to build the largest cellulosic ethanol plant in the world, in Macedonia, running on switchgrass grown on marginal abandoned land (which we actually did- and it's still there in Macedonia if anyone wants to look at it). We are, as far as we know, the only people on the planet who could bridge Dr. Field's theory with actual data. We don't know Dr. Field. He has never contacted us. His work is certainly for us in no way informative; it is not even informed.
To our surprise, when we ran the numbers based on how things work in the real world, our corn ethanol has 80% GHG savings. Our switchgrass ethanol would have had 60-70% GHG savings. That was not the only reason that project was never built, but this is an important lesson. Lest anyone cheekily claim that our LCA doesn't include fertiliser or transport or anything else, this is a full LCA, not biased one way or another, with lots an lots of actual inputs instead of default values. It is what is required by law of any biofuel in the European Union.
Out of touch academics like Dr. Field, who collect data only through desk research and who know so little about what that data represents (how people actually farm, how much natural gas is actually used, what conversion rations are practicable vs. what is promoted) do no service to climate research, and they often impede actual climate progress.
Biofuels are needed to displace oil. Any biofuel that is better than oil deserves support. The academic fervour to identify the "best biofuel" is misguided both because we need lots of things to displace oil, not just one, and because academics are certain to get it wrong in identifying what is best (until they start getting mud on their shoes rather than simply scrolling the Internet).
Dr. Field's 2009 article was dead wrong because it used absurd data. Rather than search for better data, Field is not engaged in even more abstract theorising. That's not what this debate needs, Theory needs to be based on actual data.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521456736000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we need lots of things to displace oil and because academics are certain to get it wrong in identifying what is best', u'effect': u'the academic fervour to identify the biofuel is misguided both'}, {u'cause': u'academics are certain to get it wrong in identifying what is best', u'effect': u'because we need lots of things to displace oil and'}, {u'cause': u'it used absurd data', u'effect': u"dr. field 's 2009 article was dead wrong"}], u'author_id': u'100074623', u'id': u'113739782', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AvMichelCroz', u'text': u'Hydro where feasible. Nuclear where not feasible. Wind and solar in niche applications - in particular coupled with hydro. Potentially some natural gas. Local conditions may favour some storage. Possible Bly batteries in case pumped hydro not available.

Great expanses such as the Beacons are covered with heather because that’s the reliable natural cover that is part of that ecosystem.
BQEND
The Beacons are not covered in 'great expanses' of heather- and besides the farming is restricted in national parks. But even without restrictions the farming is not maintaining nature- and half the time it is at war with it.
Heather/Heath is a preclimatic ecology- often associated with either wetland heath or dry heath [as Heathrow was- non productive farmland they turned into an airport]- the 'natural' process is colonisation by hardy plants like the heathers, some grasses and rushes- the soil is acid making it difficult for broad leaf trees. Scotpine and willow would be the first to arrive, followed by birch, rowen- as the soil became less acid woodland trees that compete by shading arrive and become dominant- such as lime and oak, with hazel and ash able to get a foot hold.
And woodland, coppice, wetland [beavers] etc have far greater water capacity than monocrops of heather for raising grouse.
Left to there own devices the Breacon Beacons would be covered in mixed woodland and the heather pushed out. Grazers will create clearings, where heather can survive, beavers will create wetlands so pushing up acidity in the soil or at least maintaining it. Fire is an early part of colonisation - heather, pine, and gorse have potential for destructive wild fires [I know them first hand]- but the coppice prone trees recover quickly.
Shooting grouse moors are empty and devoid of diversity- they are little better than sheep grazing- but the industry loves to kid its self that its 'natural ' although at £2,000 a brace that is taking the piss.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521286594000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that \u2019s the reliable natural cover that is part of that ecosystem', u'effect': u'bqstart great expanses such as the beacons are covered with heather'}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'113651802', u'id': u'113667231', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'Not quite sure what your point is here. Yes, some Amazon forest was apparently quite widely used for crop-growing, but are you suggesting this makes it reasonable to cut it down now?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521286223000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'113651958', u'id': u'113666993', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'That very much depends on the nature of the agriculture. Firstly, a huge proportion of the world's rainforest has been destroyed since the Amazon was last used for crops- so it is now a rare resource in a way it wasn't previously. Secondly, the agriculture practiced by the 'indigenous' people was very different from any large-scale farming now- if you're suggesting clear-felling to practice intensive agriculture, I'd say absolutely no, partly because the soil is thin and would require enormous inputs, not to mention the decimation of the forest's CO2 absorbtion capacity. Some form of 'forest-farming' might be appropriate, which would be more in-line with what would have previously been practiced.Either way, I'm not really sure why this would help anything much- perhaps giving the forest a long-term commercial value to compete with logging and cattle ranching.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521449704000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'partly the soil is thin and would require enormous inputs', u'effect': u"if you 're suggesting clear felling i 'd say absolutely no"}], u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'113693827', u'id': u'113733808', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'I've never come across that website factchecker before Anthony. The difference between EV and ICE is the fuel in energy terms is 1/4, and that EV juice could come from clean energy.
We could of course make cars lighter- back in the 60s the Mini weighed 600 kg, today a new mini weighs 1,400 Kg - less weight less batteries, less energy, better range.But with a size war the most popular cars are SUVs - which weigh over 2 tonnes.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521449518000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the batteries', u'effect': u"it 's embedded energy- evs have slightly more embedded energy but ice have them as well"}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'113683528', u'id': u'113733702', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'biofuel was the only fuel 200 years ago in Europe, and in many places especially across Africa biofuel is the main cooking fuel. The UKs historic biofuel industry is all around- if you take walk in a local woodland of any age it was probably originally coppice or pollard- fuel for a number of industries.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521449041000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'113720584', u'id': u'113733460', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anteaus', u'text': u'Commuter culture is indeed a plague on society, and it arises through zoning regulations which force people to live remote from their work, and insanely high house prices in localities where jobs are plentiful, eg London. 
I'm not sure what proportion of total car, bus and rail mileage is made up of commuting, but I suspect it's a major part. The answer to this is to change the factors in society that force people to commute. After all, nobody enjoys commuting. How world’s farmland is shrinking, and why it could be a good thing
BQSTART
The landscapes might be different but all are evidence of a startling new trend. For the first time in recorded history, the world’s farmland is shrinking. Every two years, an area roughly the size of Britain is abandoned. Has humanity’s insatiable land grab reached a turning point? And can we take this opportunity to build a world in which farming has a smaller footprint, and where nature can rebound from the toll we have inflicted upon it?

There is a clear tree line that appears altitude specific.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521356254000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'113667231', u'id': u'113693933', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'guest90', u'text': u'There have been developments in this area recently; most notably Exxon producing an algae-based biofuel in large concrete basins with salt water.
BQSTART
Today’s biofuels generally come from food crops such as corn and sugar, and so compete for agricultural land and fresh water. Algae can be grown in concrete ponds of salt water, on barren or desert land. 
Production of advanced biofuels made from algae could grow rapidly in the late 2020s, according to Synthetic Genomics, the biotech company that has formed a partnership with ExxonMobil to develop the fuel.
The two companies said last week that by 2025 they were aiming to set up one or more demonstration plants to produce 10,000 barrels a day of diesel and jet fuel from genetically modified algae. Synthetic Genomics argues that scaling up production could be relatively quick. 
The aim is to produce biofuels that will be cost competitive with conventional oil-based fuels at crude prices of about $60 to $65 a barrel. 
Oliver Fetzer, chief executive of Synthetic Genomics, said: “Once we’re past 2025, if our trajectory stays on track, there’s no reason why we would not be able to scale up quickly.”
BQEND

https://www.ft.com/content/f31c4778-267a-11e8-b27e-cc62a39d57a0
Another avenue that Audi are pursuing now are the 'Sunflow' e-fuels made purely from bacteria, any type of water, and a carbon dioxide stream. However, looking at the website it seems obvious that the way they are using this carbon dioxide is to utilise a lot of it in bulk at concentrations that are unlikely to be derived from just biomass - so its just getting a second use out of carbon, using bacteria. Interesting, but not technically a biofuel and wholly dependent on the source of CO2.https://fleetworld.co.uk/audi-makes-breakthrough-in-e-gas-prodution/
The absolute best answer to the question of bio-based fuels is a combination of these types of things used specifically for air travel, which I think is going to be difficult to decarbonise considering the maturity of the various technologies currently in use, and the testing etc required to effect a change to a new technology.
What genuinely needs to happen is a wholesale shift to bio-gas/biomethane. The advantages of biogas are as follows and can be easily verified by farmers' reports, studies etc - this is what needs to happen.a) Biogas is carbon negative as the remaining substrate from AD units goes back on the soilb) This reduces or replaces the fossil fertilizer that would otherwise be usedc) Not using fossil fertilizer halts the chemical decomposition of the soil, which halts the emission of nitrous oxides - a powerful GHGd) Fertilizer pollution and run-off are minimised, as can be verifiede) This industrially-produced organic fertilizer creates healthier, more climate-resiliant crops that need less waterf) Obviously the farmer is producing a lot of energy which within an effective logistics environment, produces approx €800,000 of biogas per silo annuallyg) Various local quality of life impacts such as reduced smell etc.
Many gas network operators and providers plan to reduce their carbon emissions before 2050. This is because it can be cheaper than refitting a very old metal gas network, or some appliances (potentially, we are still waiting for studies on this) for hydrogen. Plastic pipes work a lot better with no problems regarding an increased pressure within the pipe, and various issues. So if a country cannot or does not want to go 100% hydrogen, then combining biogas with hydrogen can both make up a significant proportion of domestic gas use with zero change to appliances or pipes. This is because biogas contains carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide which are easy to combine with hydrogen via biomethanation; producing a chemically-identical gas to the one we use today in most homes. Of overall domestic gas use in most western countries (without including transport of industry), this biogas could replace over 1/3 of domestic consumption; and in combination with H2 about two-thirds. With fuel cells or higher efficiency; lower demand, the figure is close to 100% - this is why many studies point to this being a viable and cost-effective route for gas companies to take going out to 2050. Personally, I believe hydrogen will play a more prominant role but certainly biogas is very much a growth industry and carries many other advantages for agriculture that cannot be avoided if we are to cope with these various problems concurrently.

It's a natural CO2 sink as the plant is growing.”
I am pleased for you, having this positive experience. 
My direct experience of agriculture, having grown up in farming country, is that it is an intensely industrialised process that is extremely intolerant of nature. It systematically poisons and eradicates anything other than the narrow range of plants and animals it produces. Bird populations are continuing to plummet, insects have been devastated and bees are under threat around the world because of powerful insecticides. The industry is not kind to its practitioners either, with exposure to powerful carcinogens such as found in sheep dip. 
Looking for farmers to save us from oil barons is a bit like the old lady who swallowed a fly. And then hilariously swallows a spider to fix it. And so on. 
Some bio-energy makes sense. Like some wind and solar in appropriate niches. But these are all fiddling around the edges rather than addressing Central issues of copious cheap reliable and sustainable alternatives to fossil fuels. 
A good read of David Mackay’s “sustainable energy - without the hot air” is very educative.

David is sadly missed. His excellent analysis “Sustainable energy without the hot air” is wonderfully revealing of the realistic options we face, taking Britain as an example. He looks at a range of viable alternatives for sustainable energy supply, minimising fossil carbon emissions. Biofuel (predominately in the form of wood burning and of energy recovered from biowaste) is a small component of any of the options he shows. 
So many of the “feelgood” and fashionable “alternatives” simply evaporate when viewed by scientists as part of the bigger picture and in real-world contexts outside the ivory towers, and outside vested interests and special interest groups. 
If only there were more like David. He is sorely missed.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521234712000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'113585645', u'id': u'113651267', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AvMichelCroz', u'text': u'“Without rereading the article ... it specifies marginal land: poorly performing agricultural land.”
Where will Nature go now? In places such as Britain, it has been a struggle to reclaim any land from industrial agriculture for nature corridors and islands to allow at least some space for something other than industrial monocultures. In large swathes of sub-Saharan Africa there is direct competition between biofuels and growing of food. The “marginal” areas are often game reserves and areas of retreat for wildlife under pressure from increasing populations. 
The challenge of growing sufficient food in a changing world is frequently cited as an argument for accelerating action against climate change. 
Calls for a renewed focus on biofuels, with the obvious increased pressure that this will exert on wildlife and “natural” (unfarmed) environments is something of an eye-opener. This is one of the champions of action against climate change writing this article. But this looks like just one more short-sighted economic initiative. Like building extensive wind farms in South Australia that now need even greater expenditure on energy storage to make them reliable and to recover the value of the initial investment. The right decision would have been to build nuclear capacity at the outset, in a State hosting perhaps the world’s greatest uranium mine. 
Clearly conservation of nature, and sustainability, is not a high priority for you.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521234022000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'113587219', u'id': u'113650950', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NJrubble', u'text': u'you may well be correct about the UK. in the US there is a great deal of land used for agriculture only by virue of the application of energy and so forth. biodiversity is important, but easier to achieve here, provided we take appropriate measures.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521320169000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11116663', u'in_reply_to': u'113521618', u'id': u'113682417', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NJrubble', u'text': u'i agree with your conclusion. but if as seems the case, society will require liquid fuel for some forms of activity (transit by air for example) it seems worthwhile to consider appropriately sourced biofuel. i don't doubt your reports of destructive practices in some parts of the world, but that's not really relevant to a consideration of biofuel produced on marginal or useless (as in unsuitable for intensive, continuous agricultural use) land within, for example, the contiguous 48 states.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521319832000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11116663', u'in_reply_to': u'113529173', u'id': u'113682233', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'OPuhleez', u'text': u'And is cost of safe and permanent nuclear waste storage for the life of the radioactive wastes (250,000 years or so) factored in...? And brainless siting of reactors in earthquake zones like Fukushima...?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521231132000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12623478', u'in_reply_to': u'113560817', u'id': u'113649732', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'evolution rhythm', u'text': u'"This is another great example of clean energy technologies that will help us solve the climate problem while continuing our use of fuels that drive the economy. It’s a win-win situation."
I'd be interested to see research that examined the amount of land required to produce sufficient amounts of biofuels to burn for the UK's transportation systems. In contrast to ecological reports that suggest, in general, the UK's land management ( historically) has severely neglected the fact that land isn't merely a area of space their for human exploitation, it's a component of a ecosystem. Ecosystems where many species evolved.
I think, in general, the same monetary values, above and beyond ecological awareness, remain at the heart of many people's decision making processes.
Of course society needs energy. However, we have become accustomed to having a economic system that gives us all we want ( more stuff and more power) rather than focusing on we need ( a comparably stable climate, clean air and water etc). 
In many communities this " win,win " hypothesis ( neutral carbon) means they have digressed environmentally as potentially biodiverse habitats ( using evidenced based conservation biology, ecology etc) are changed to provide biofuel plantations of conifer tree's for people to burn in their homes thus emit the polutents where they live. 
There is much cognitive dissonance regarding environmental issues and a hell of alot of ignorance. Thus l wouldn't be surprised in 30 years or society has simply shifted the problems of CO2 emissions ( one one part of the problem. E.g. Deforestation, habitat loss, over fishing, ) into other area's ( e.g. polutents from burning biofuels and the huge amounts of land required for plantations). 
Whilst the tribal nature of humans has meant that, what should be a scientifically informed direction of travel has become a political football. A game we are only just waking up to find we've been backing the losing side as humans can not out compete the planet's ecosystem.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521223591000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15713576', u'id': u'113646645', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NJrubble', u'text': u'interesting that the press release itself states that the result is irrational. it may be that certain policies are best set by public opinion, but in cases like this where policymakers must rely upon experts to make any kind of rational choice, arguing about public opinion is a distracting, irrelevant sideshow. the oceans will expand even if 95% of americans are opposed to their doing so.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521318887000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11116663', u'in_reply_to': u'113556625', u'id': u'113681755', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NJrubble', u'text': u'the issue isn't whether to pay, but rather when and how much. society as a whole will incur potentially staggering costs from climate change. the question is whether we should attemp paying something now so as to forestall paying more later. it might even be possible to argue to wait and pay later, but to do so it would be necessary to show why that might be a plausibly rational choice.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521318308000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11116663', u'in_reply_to': u'113515892', u'id': u'113681408', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GeraldLandry', u'text': u'Good points, in Africa they were evicting Subsistence farmers for Corporate Monocropped sugar cane for ethanol. description: John Abraham: We’re not yet optimizing biofuel production for both economic and environmental factors
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: We’re not yet optimizing biofuel production for both economic and environmental factors
og_fields.og:title: Biofuels can help solve climate change, especially with a carbon tax | John Abraham
text:
Facing the reality of human-caused warming, we now look for ways to reduce the problem so that future generations will not inherit a disaster. So, what can we do now to help the future? 
The easiest answer is to use energy more wisely and quit wasting our precious resources. Second, we can increase our use of clean energy, particularly wind and solar power. These are great starts but we will still need some liquid fuels and for those, we can make decisions about the best fuels for the environment. There has been extensive conversation recently about biofuels and how they may help solve the climate problem. 
The term “biofuels” has many meanings, but basically they are grown fuels (like corn ethanol) that we can use instead of fossil fuels (like petroleum). While biofuels can be any fuel produced from plant material, historically they have been produced from food crops such as corn and soy. But, new technologies are enabling biofuel production from non-edible gases, wood, and other plant waste material.
The beauty of biofuels is that they suck carbon dioxide out of the air as they grow. When we burn them in our automobiles, we release carbon dioxide, but it is the same carbon that the plants absorbed while growing. Just on that basis, biofuels appear to be zero net emitters. 
But this view is too simplistic. It takes energy to grow biofuels; it takes fertilizer, tractors, transportation, and energy to convert the plants to liquid fuels. Planting and growing these crops can also change how much carbon is stored in the soil. And using existing food crops or arable land for biofuel production might lead to deforestation if farms are expanded elsewhere to make up for lost food production.
 So, if you want to accurately assess the impact of biofuels, you need to look at what’s called a “life cycle analysis,” which basically means the effort it takes to grow the crops, harvest them, convert them to fuel, transport them to distribution sites, and combust them. 
I have done some research in this area. Back in 2009, I did a study with my former student Fushcia-Ann Hoover, and we compared different feedstocks for ethanol. You can have corn, soybeans, sugarcane, switchgrass, poplar trees, and others. What is the best crop? Which is easiest to grow? Which is best for the environment?
What we found, way back in 2009, is that if non-commercial crops were grown, you could actually end up with fuel that was significantly cleaner than petroleum. The trick was finding clean crops that don’t need a lot of fertilizer, water, and other inputs. Corn ethanol for instance is not the best choice. You need so much water, fertilizer, and other costs, that it almost doesn’t make it worthwhile. But other crops such as switchgrass, grown on marginal lands, have real a potential. Marginal lands are farmlands that are not optimal for growing crops.
Our conclusion in 2009 was straightforward. Don’t use good cropland for biofuels. Rather, use marginal croplands, with minimal water and fertilizer, to create plants that can be converted to biofuels. 
But our conclusion wasn’t the end of the story. There are other details that researchers should consider. For instance, how far from the croplands to the refinery? How much energy is needed to transport the fuels? All these issues matter and they were the focus of a recent research paper just published in Nature Energy. This study used an actual biofuel refinery located in Kansas for the basis of the study. And the authors counted all the emissions that occur during the lifecycle analysis of these biofuels. They realized that marginal croplands give lower yields, so there are competing issues of productivity and greenhouse gas reduction.
Then there’s the complicating factor of economics. The price of biofuels and the price of greenhouse gases matter. If society is willing to pay a small pollution charge like a carbon tax, it supports the producers of clean energy. But if society doesn’t put a premium on clean energy, it’s harder for clean industry companies to thrive.
In the new study, the authors discovered something fascinating. The found that the choices a farmer may make regarding what land to use for biofuels and how much fertilizer to use depend strongly on the price of clean fuels and the cost of greenhouse gases. Simply put, it we put a reasonable price on carbon pollution, farmers will be able to grow switchgrass, poplars, and other species, reduce greenhouse gases, and make money. 
But, if there is no cost to carbon pollution, farmers will be motivated to spend more money on fertilizer and that, in the end, will lead to more emissions. While all the scenarios resulted in large emissions reductions compared to gasoline, the reductions were especially large for the scenarios that included a carbon price. 
So, there is a delicate balance. The balance is made more clear when we realize that farming location matters. If biofuels are grown close to refineries, less pollution is created in transporting the fuels to the refinery. However, this limits cropland choices to those nearer to refineries. 
With this balance of competing factors, the authors find room for improvement; currently we are not optimizing the performance in terms of both economic and environmental factors. In order to do this right, we have to balance all these mentioned issues. We can’t just focus on transportation costs, fertilizer costs, and land quality costs; we have to consider these costs all together as a system.
I spoke to the lead author of the paper, Dr. John Field, from Colorado State University and asked him about the significance of this work.
Agriculture is being challenged by increasing food demand, and changes to regional climate. On top of this, most plans to combat climate change rely on the agricultural sector to increase carbon storage in soils, and to produce raw materials for the large-scale production of biofuels and power. Modeling studies like ours attempt to predict on a farm-by-farm basis where the best opportunities for biofuel crop production and soil carbon storage lie, how much they might cost, and how those two goals trade off. 
Our results suggest that biofuels can have a wide range of environmental outcomes depending on exactly where and how those crops are grown, but climate benefits can be increased at relatively low cost.
This is another great example of clean energy technologies that will help us solve the climate problem while continuing our use of fuels that drive the economy. It’s a win-win situation.

We have been indoctrinated with various lies over the years extolling the virtues of Big Business empire building, for the jobs /products created with scant evaluation of the overall damage that has been caused to water quality, land/food sustainability, actual quality of life/environment, and the increasing disparity in the share of wealth. BQSTART
They know the game is up so their playing along
BQEND
I should think that's an improvement. Do you think it would be better if Exxon actively opposed the Paris agreement and published climate change denial documents attacking it? The Paris agreement is pretty much toothless, but still better than nothing.
Unfortunately the game is "not up" for oil and to a large extent gas. Incidentally the oil and gas companies are far more in touch with reality on this question in terms of current conditions. Conditions may change, but unfortunately that's the way it is right now. They are a very long way from being stupid.
Much is made of EVs and they are going to make a contribution to emissions reduction. How much and how fast remains to be seen. But they are not going to put oil companies out of business anytime soon. Road passages vehicles (cars, buses, motorbikes etc) only account for about 25% of global oil consumption. There's a scarcity of good options to get rid of the other 75% right now. 
Few seem to able to put in any sort of effort into thinking about why oil companies want a carbon price. It's simple. They want a predicable regulatory environment for business planning which actually has quite a long time frame. It's something they can live with. Additional BILLIONS of future generations are to be condemned to poverty, suffering and death because of Dire Inaction on global warming.
AFTER 80 YEARS the orthodoxy of unscientific, ignorant, faith based, greed has been OVERTURNED yet vast challenges remain. 
New York Times: 1956 The Rising Threat of Carbon Dioxide
Society must begin to adapt to a rapidly changing climate. 19th and 20th century fossil fuel dinosaurs cling to their free pollution, resisting scientific enlightenment and political action. Plutocrats like Trump and the Koch Bro's hold back urgently needed societal change.
The Guardian, the long road to enlightenment
The consensus peer-reviewed climate science: GLOBAL WARMING is occurring at an accelerated rate in a short geological timeframe and this will affect all species and life on planet earth. Climate mitigation and adaptation actions are urgently required.
The trillion dollar question is - do you believe the projection that the exponential rate of human population growth will start to slow down this century? Youtube David Attenborough on Overpopulation
At our present rate of resource use, whilst factoring technological innovation "collapse is not avoided but simply delayed by one to two decades - and when it occurs the speed of decline is even greater".
Turner: An Updated Comparison of TheLimits to Growth with Historical Data
Collectively, governments must effectively price the pollution of those large corporations which service humanities ever-growing needs. The world needs to adapt economies for the 21st century and beyond with the same level of collective determination as achieved when nations go to war. Lest the plutocrats unleash a war of terrible proportions in an attempt to save their skins... Nero fiddles whilst Rome burns.
If you hate your children or this planet - do nothing. 
Otherwise, wake up! Educate yourself as best you can, think critically, and then help inform your family, friends, your community. Advocate for systemic change.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521161644000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'dire inaction on global warming', u'effect': u'to be condemned to poverty'}], u'author_id': u'100013165', u'id': u'113613506', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AvMichelCroz', u'text': u'“Fair point but yours makes no sense to me.”
I’m not sure that people would have chosen to eat short-faced bears, or dire wolves. But despite potential prey in their millions, in the form of the American Bison, both these dangerous predators disappeared. 
So it would appear fair to speculate that, if any human agency were involved, the killing would have been at least partly deliberate. 
Similarly, hunting mammoths would have been an extremely dangerous business, with the return on effort limited by the time before the carcass would be inedible or attract too much scavengers attention. But they were hunted to extinction. Bison, on the other hand, might well be spot on for large family groups. 
However, I was only speculating, and find it very odd that you felt it necessary to assert that I was in error. description: Empty rhetoric from corporates is not enough as climate change is accelerating far faster than expected
og_fields.og:description: Empty rhetoric from corporates is not enough as climate change is accelerating far faster than expected
og_fields.og:title: If business leaders want to regain our trust, they must act upon climate risk | Ian Dunlop
text:
Business leaders seem astonished that community trust in their activities is at an all-time low, trending toward the bottom of the barrel inhabited by politicians. To the corporate leader dedicated to the capitalist, market economy success story of the last 50 years, that attitude is no doubt incomprehensible and downright ungrateful.
But it is hardly surprising given continuing scandals and declining ethics across the corporate and banking worlds, driven by the pernicious impact of short-termism, rising inequality and undue political influence; in large part the outcome of the oxymoron of “pay-for-performance” remuneration. So how is trust regained? The need for stronger leadership, ethics, greater transparency, open communications and improved culture feature prominently in current responses. 
But a far more fundamental requirement is ignored, namely that business must lead on really critical issues, particularly the point raised long ago by economist Kenneth Boulding: “Anyone who considers economic growth can continue indefinitely in a finite system is either a madman or an economist”. The constraints Boulding anticipated have now arrived, as burgeoning population and economic growth crash into global biophysical limits which cannot be circumvented.
Those constraints, encompassing resource shortages, biodiversity loss and pollution in various guises, do not feature in the capitalist economic lexicon, as technology and the market are supposed to overcome all as we march toward the sunlit uplands of the neoliberal nirvana. In the real world, the entire growth model under which Australia and global economies operate, is no longer sustainable; it sowed the seeds of its own destruction some time ago and is rapidly driving itself into the ground as growth rates decline. This is the great “black elephant” of business and politics; a known, knowable fact that no one wants to acknowledge – the unmentionable in the recent Business and Governance Summits around the country, as our leaders strive to compound the problem with self-defeating subterfuges to maximise growth, not least corporate tax cuts and trade agreements.
To the community, these constraints are increasingly obvious as the quality of life for the average person deteriorates in myriad ways. The rhetoric of much-vaunted corporate social responsibility no longer holds water when our supposed leaders are not prepared to address the issues that really count for our survival, let alone prosperity. 
These range from basic considerations such as ensuring food and water availability, to the creation of genuinely sustainable global societies. However, the first priority must be human-induced climate change, manifest as the lack of an atmosphere into which we can continue dumping carbon pollution from the burning of fossil fuels, agriculture and deforestation, without causing catastrophic consequences. 
Climate change is accelerating far faster than expected, to the point where it now represents an existential threat to humanity, that is a threat posing permanent large negative consequences which will be irreversible, an outcome being locked in today by our insistence on expanding the use of fossil fuels. This should be a major concern in Australia given that we are more exposed than most, but instead our leaders would have us embark on massive fossil fuel expansion. Already one of the world’s largest carbon polluters when exports are included, Australia is complicit in destroying the conditions which make human life possible. There is no greater crime against humanity.
The economic and social impacts will be devastating unless that policy is rapidly reversed. The unprecedented hurricane season in the Atlantic, bushfires in the Californian winter, extreme heat in many parts of South Asia and rapid heating of the Arctic with associated instability in the northern hemisphere weather system, are only the most recent portents of what is to come. The worst outcomes can only be avoided now by emergency action, akin to restructuring economies on a war-footing.
It finally seems to be dawning on corporate and investor leadership that climate change is a real and present danger which is not going away.
Company directors are personally liable for failing to assess and act upon climate risk, but the greenwash continues. Major corporates parade their credentials in support of serious climate action, but none of their scenarios and policies are in line with the Paris objective of constraining global temperature increase “well below 2.0C above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the increase to 1.50C”.
Fortunately, as understanding of the risks improves, regulatory pressure mounts. The recommendations triggered by Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, via the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosure (TCFD) are gradually being taken up, with companies voluntarily disclosing the impact which a 2C policy framework would have on their organisation, assuming such a framework was ever put in place (by governments?). Progress, but reactive and certainly not leadership. The question that must be answered is: “what are you doing proactively as a company to create a 2C world” – more realistically closer to 1.5C, as it is now patently clear that 2C is far too high?
If business genuinely wishes to regain trust, it must proactively face up to the challenge posed by climate change and initiate emergency action. Beyond that, it must open up honest debate on a new economic model to replace conventional growth. It is the only way business will be sustainable in the 21st century with a real social licence to operate.
In Churchill’s words: “Sometimes we have to do what is required”.
• Ian Dunlop was formerly an international oil, gas and coal industry executive, chair of the Australian Coal Association and CEO of the Australian Institute of Company Director

[{u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'clearly being a conspiracy theorist is a condition- I have known friends who were truthers and it was impossible to use facts to get them think.For years I quite enjoyed the Apollo conspiracies [not the wacky aliens or Nazis on the far side] just the need to ensure a cold war pr stunt- but I was always open to answers.In the main people with freaky views tend to be quiet, but in the group setting people will join in the mob mentality and with enough peer pressure as in some communities AGW denial can take hold.
and then being a conspiracy nut is dangerous.the problem with our friend here is any acceptance of any point is a weakness that will lead to the total collapse of his world view. He is an extremist zealot in religious terms rather than CoE- the shouty cult member who actually is a liability.The lukewarmers are more of a danger- they can be reasonable, accepting but far more effective and scheming.
The US is a getting a lot of flax at the moment- but curiously Russia plays the game better- despite not being a huge problem country [its oil will run out as reduction of CO2 kicks in] it talks the Paris agreement talk but walks its own denial. although in the grand mother Russia terms the world may get a bit screwed but they should [sort of] be ok and perhaps better.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521288794000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'the total collapse of his world view'}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'113667010', u'id': u'113668383', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'The fringe throws up 'CO2 is not a greenhouse gas/weak GHG' papers every year- they are never in serious journals - it is always some physicist with a pet cranky idea and when anybody can be asked is quickly debunked.
Seriously if these papers had a hint of accuracy, first it would throw what we know about the atmosphere into complete flux- heat seeking missiles would stop working - the 1C warming we have already experienced - the melting Arctic, the retreating glaciers, the earlier arrival of spring would need a new mechanism.
It would be the ultimate mystery- and I'm sure enough scientists would break ranks with the mainstream to find an explanation.
But denial is a conspiracy theorists playground.Point to global warming data record- and apparently it is cooling, or not happening, or every one of the world's weather agencies has meddled with the data.Yet no evidence, no smoking gun.This is a major conspiracy involving 1000s of data collection points with 1000s of people doing the work, and 1000s of scientists involved with the conspiracy- yet not one whistle blower in 20 or more years.
But say you [although you don't] accepted the world is warming, the Arctic is declining- then it has to be natural, because a few papers say CO2 is a GHG.We know the sun is less active, they spent a fortune creating a cloud machine to cosmic rays [which don't have much effect], we do know oceans go through warming and cooling cycles- and despite them we see warming.....what magic is happening?The world's greatest mystery and these physicists who write 'co2 is weak GHG' cannot be asked to research the greatest modern mystery.

description: Havoc as heavy snow affects US east coast, cyclones brush New Zealand and Arctic sea ice melts
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: Havoc as heavy snow affects US east coast, cyclones brush New Zealand and Arctic sea ice melts
og_fields.og:title: World weatherwatch: Nor'easter whips against US as cyclones slam South Pacific
text:
Cyclone Hola continued its path south-eastwards across the South Pacific this week, brushing along the northern-most fringes of New Zealand’s North Island. The cyclone, which intensified to category 4, brought with it heavy rain and strong winds in excess of 70mph to communities along the Bay of Plenty and Gisborne as well as to the country’s capital, Auckland. It was the third big storm to strike the country this year.
Across the Atlantic, in the northern and eastern parts of the US, a second “nor’easter” as coined by American meteorologists, brought further strong winds and heavy snowfall along the east coast, affecting the states of New York, Pennsylvania and Maine last Thursday. 
A third winter storm is expected to strike during the coming days bringing strong winds and a mix of heavy rain and snowfall.
The anomalous warmth in the Arctic, which in part was responsible for the swath of exceptional cold that swept through Europe over the past few weeks, has done little to maintain the extent of the sea ice in the region, which should now be approaching its typical maximum limit.
As it stands, and within the satellite record, the sea ice extent recording seems to have put this winter within the top three for having the lowest ice extent. And there has been a reduction in the ice cover over the last three consecutive winters.

original hockey stick graph (and most of those that followed), the first half of the 20th century experienced an unprecedented temperature rise (in scale and rate) for a 1000 years!
While minor CO2 influence cannot be ruled out, the IPPC demonstrates and concludes that the early 20th century warming can be fully explained by natural drivers (mainly the Sun). It is well accepted that early 20th century CO2 emissions were insufficient to be a major driver.
Thus, by an amazing coincidence, the 20th century experienced both an unprecendeted (in 1000 years) NATURAL warming AND unprecedented MANMADE warming, one after the other. The only way to reduce atmospheric CO2 ,is by biochemical/ photosynthetic processes and by converting to carbonic acid in water. We as a species have been reducing the standing biosphere since pre industrial times ( chopped down the ancient forests and the rain forests and played a great part in desertification of north Africa). We use this land for other things now so vast swathes of the earth's surface being turned back into woodland is a none starter ( and is only a one off benefit for 100-200years anyway as trees die)The acidification of oceans can only go so far due to it being a reversible / equilibrium process dependent upon temperature. Also we started at a point of equilibrium in pre industrial times so any temporary sequestration of Co2 into seawater will change ( usually harm) the aquatic environment because of the pH alteration.Co2 cannot escape into space as the earth is a closed system ( apart from space junk)So every tonne of Co2 produced from fossilised carbon sources stays with us.So we either stop producing it or live with the consequences. og_fields.og:description: Making up for years of delay and denial will not be easy, nor will it be cheap. Climate polluters must be held accountable, says Richard Wiles, executive director of the Center for Climate Integrity
og_fields.og:title: It's 50 years since climate change was first seen. Now time is running out | Richard Wiles
text:
Fifty years ago, the Stanford Research Institute (SRI) delivered a report titled Sources, Abundance, and Fate of Gaseous Atmospheric Polluters to the American Petroleum Institute (API), a trade association for the fossil fuel industry.
The report, unearthed by researchers at the Center for International Environmental Law, is one of the earliest attempts by the industry to grapple with the impacts of rising CO2 levels, which Stanford’s researchers warned if left unabated “could bring about climatic changes” like temperature increases, melting of ice caps and sea level rise. 
The year was 1968, and the term “global warming” would not appear in a peer-reviewed academic journal until 1975. Famed Nasa scientist James Hansen would not testify before Congress that “global warming has begun” for another 20 years. And the US would not enter into – only to later pull out of – the Paris climate accord for nearly half a century.
The anniversary of SRI’s report to the API on climate change represents not just a damning piece of evidence of what the fossil fuel industry knew and when, but a signal of all that we have lost over the decades of policy inaction and interference. It should also serve as a potent motivator in the fight for climate accountability and justice.
At the time, CO2 levels in the atmosphere stood about 323ppm. The planet was warming but was still well within the historical norm. Sea levels had risen by about 4in compared with 1880 levels. The report, however, cautioned that “man is now engaged in a vast geophysical experiment with his environment, the Earth” and that “significant temperature changes are almost certain to occur by the year 2000”.
Those predictions proved to be correct: by the turn of the century, the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere had risen to 369ppm, causing a temperature increase of nearly half a degree over pre-industrial averages. Today, virtually all climate scientists agree there is little or no chance the world can stay within the goal of 1.5C, the limit of what scientists believe to be safe.
With each decade of delay and denial the impacts and costs of climate change have continued to mount
Over the next 20 years, the scientific community and policymakers around the world began to reach a consensus on the threat posed by rising CO2 levels. Scientists at least one major oil company, Exxon, did their own climate modeling, which agreed with the scientific consensus. During this period a budding movement to cut emissions began.
To counter and slow down that effort to address climate change, the fossil fuel industry began its long and powerful strategy of climate denial and obstructionism. Even though they knew the science, they also realized that attempts to control emissions could seriously damage their bottom lines.
In 1998, as the first global attempt to rein in climate pollution, the Kyoto protocol, was headed to the Senate for ratification, API circulated what has come to be known as the Victory Memo, a detailed road map to undermining science and promoting denial of climate change. According to API’s top strategists: “Victory will be achieved when: those promoting the Kyoto treaty on the basis of extant science appear to be out of touch with reality.”
The memo’s end goal was clear: create doubt about science where none existed, deceive the media and Congress about the risks of climate change, and block the momentum that was building to address rising emissions through the Kyoto protocol, a precursor to the Paris accord. ExxonMobil alone would go on to spend upwards of $30m on ads, front groups, and pseudoscience intended to carry out the plan. That’s in addition to the cash that flooded the coffers of climate deniers in Congress who are rewarded amply for willful ignorance.
API’s strategic deception campaign was a success, which is why we now stand at the brink of the highest global temperature considered safe. Just what it will mean to cross that line remains an ongoing question for atmospheric scientists, but we’ve already started to get a glimpse and it doesn’t look good.
The damage is all around us, from hurricanes on steroids – scientists attribute 15-40% (8in-24in) of the epic rain of Hurricane Harvey to climate change – to California’s deadly wildfires which were set up by five years of drought, followed by record snowfall, then record heat that turned huge areas of the state into tinderboxes. In 2017 there were 16 separate billion-dollar disasters in the US, resulting in a total of $306bn of damages, nearly $100bn more than the second highest year 2005 (Katrina). While technically climate change did not “cause” these disasters, most of the carnage was aggravated in some way by climate change and the fossil fuel emissions that cause it in the first place.
Other impacts are more long-term and irreparable. Anyone born after 1985 has never experienced a month with average temperatures that fall below the historical norm and, without action, probably never will. Mass coral bleaching events due to warming waters and ocean acidification have rendered large swaths of some of the ocean’s most diverse ecosystems lifeless. The vanishing Arctic ice cap appears already to be affecting global weather patterns, and the loss of ice in Antarctica may have reached a tipping point that many now view as irreversible, a development that will require tough and costly decisions for coastal cities.
It never had to be this way. But with each decade of delay and denial the impacts and costs of climate change have continued to mount. Now taxpayers are left holding the bill for a literal rising tide of impacts that pose the greatest challenge humanity has ever faced. Meeting that challenge must begin with accountability on the part of climate polluters, and justice for citizens who did nothing to cause the problem other than drive to work and heat their homes when they had no other alternatives.
We can’t turn back the clock, but we can turn off the fossil fuel firehose that’s been pumping CO2 into our atmosphere and demand that those who left it running help foot the bill for the cleanup. Already we’ve seen cities like New York, San Francisco, and other coastal cities file lawsuits against climate polluters, seeking to recover costs associated with planning for and adapting to a warming world. With massive costs facing hundreds more cities and no remedy in sight, more litigation will follow.
Making up for 50 years of delay and denial will not be easy, nor will it be cheap. But taxpayers should not have to shoulder the burden alone. The API and its climate polluters knowingly and deliberately caused this mess. They must help pay to clean it up.

description: Letters: Academics and environmental campaigners from the Beyond Extinction Economics (BEE) network say challenging questions about confronting the risk to global biodiversity were left unanswered by a recent Guardian briefing article
og_fields.og:description: Letters: Academics and environmental campaigners from the Beyond Extinction Economics (BEE) network say challenging questions about confronting the risk to global biodiversity were left unanswered by a recent Guardian briefing article
og_fields.og:title: Awkward questions about biodiversity | Letters
text:
Damian Carrington are to be congratulated on a wide-ranging and informative article on the urgency and scale of the current global threat to biodiversity and the Guardian (What is biodiversity and why does it matter to us?, theguardian.com, 12 March). However, we of the Beyond Extinction Economics (BEE) network have reservations about the article’s diagnosis of its causes, and proposals for addressing the crisis.
First, to say “we” or “human activity” is responsible for biodiversity loss sidesteps the more serious challenge of identifying the specific socio-cultural, and, more centrally, economic drivers of destruction. Second, to slip easily from population rises to industrial development, housing and farming as the causes of the destruction of wild areas evades critical questions about what sort of industry, producing what sort of consumer goods and what kind of farming and food distribution system – let alone questions as to who has the power to decide and who gets to consume and who doesn’t.
Proposing remedies such as commercial big game hunting and “sustainable” tourism misses the central point of the article’s analysis: while loss of iconic big mammals is dreadful, the future of humanity and of life itself is threatened by deeper, wider and less visible processes such as the vast scale of loss of invertebrate species and populations, soil microorganisms and oceanic flora. The drastic declines in biodiversity not only compete with climate change for importance, but are intertwined with it and with the other processes of environmental degradation which together constitute a multi-dimensional crisis in the relationship between the dynamics of our global economy and society and the earth that sustains us. As to “natural capital”, this approach is well meant but risks of capitulating to the language and values of the very economic forces that are the most powerful drivers of destruction. Popular pressure and inter-governmental cooperation to restrain these forces by such measures as planning and regulation are urgently needed. In the longer term, only deep economic and social transformations give us any hope of a liveable and genuinely sustainable world.
 
Victor AndersonTed Benton Professor emeritus, University of Essex, and Red-Green Study GroupJohn Blewitt Schumacher InstituteRussell Elliott Compas, CymruBrian Heatley Green HouseJenneth Parker Schumacher InstituteIan RappelPritam Singh Professor of economics, Oxford Brookes UniversityMartin Stott Chair, Garden OrganicSian Sullivan Professor of environment and culture, Bath Spa University
• Join the debate – email guardian.letters@theguardian.com
• Read more Guardian letters – click here to visit gu.com/letters

description: Industrial sites have spent millions on carbon credits under Direct Action’s ‘safeguard mechanism’
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: Industrial sites have spent millions on carbon credits under Direct Action’s ‘safeguard mechanism’
og_fields.og:title: Offsets for emissions breaches prove Australia has a carbon market, Labor says
text:
Sixteen Australian industrial sites have breached government-imposed greenhouse gas emissions limits and had to buy millions of dollars in carbon credits.
The breaches came despite big emitters being granted generous carbon limits, in many cases above their highest previous pollution levels.
They were revealed in the first batch of emissions data released under the Coalition’s “safeguard mechanism”, part of the Direct Action climate policy introduced by carbon pricing opponent Tony Abbott.
Labor and industry body the Carbon Market Institute both said the use of Australian carbon credit units – mostly created through land-use based greenhouse gas reduction projects – was evidence the country had a carbon market despite the government claiming otherwise.
The opposition climate spokesman, Mark Butler, said businesses were now trading credits at prices the Coalition had claimed would wreck the economy under Labor. He said it showed the hypocrisy and ineffectiveness of the government’s approach to climate change.
“The Turnbull government should stop trying to mislead the Australian people and their own backbench,” he said. “[It should] admit that carbon pricing and trading is not only needed to take effective action on climate change, but their ineffective climate change policy also includes carbon trading.”
The Labor-Greens carbon price for all big emitters was $24.15 a tonne when the scheme was repealed and replaced by Direct Action under then prime minister Abbott in 2014. The price had been expected to fall to less than $10 a tonne the following year when international carbon trading began.
Comparatively few credits – about 448,000 – were bought last year under the safeguard mechanism, mostly for $14-$15 a tonne, suggesting a total cost to business of more than $6m.
The majority of the 154 emitters covered by the safeguard mechanism emitted less than their limit, known as a baseline, allowed last financial year. The biggest purchases of credits were by miners Anglo Coal (133,104 tonnes worth at the Capcoal mine in Queensland), Glencore (81,851 tonnes at the Tahmoor coalmine in NSW) and Rio Tinto (68,305 at the Alcan Gove bauxite mine in Arnhem Land).
The environment and energy minister, Josh Frydenberg, did not directly address whether Australia had a carbon market. He said the safeguard mechanism was developed through consultation with a broad cross-section of industry, and provided flexible options for businesses to comply.
He said Labor had introduced a carbon tax that hit households and businesses, and was now promising a deep cut in emissions by 2030 without backing it up with a plan or costings. “In contrast, the government’s approach is to address climate change with policies that ensure we have an affordable and reliable energy system and competitive industries,” Frydenberg said.
Butler said the ALP supported the further development of carbon markets. 
The safeguard mechanism was promised to ensure cuts paid for using the main part of Direct Action – the $2.55bn emission reduction fund – were not undone by emissions increasing in other parts of the economy.
Government agency the Clean Energy Regulator sets an emissions limit for each large industrial site based on its highest level of emissions over the previous five years. But companies can apply to have the limit recalculated.
Consultants RepuTex last month found 57 industrial sites had been allowed increased baselines beyond previous emissions levels, prompting claims the safeguard mechanism was pointless. The new data shows eight of these operations breached their increased baseline.
The government is now considering making the safeguard mechanism less tied to historic emissions. A climate policy review released in December suggested emission limits could be loosened so they “increase with production, supporting business growth”.
The Greens climate spokesman, Adam Bandt, said most companies were compliant under the safeguard mechanism only because the system was broken – baselines were either too high to begin with or businesses had been granted higher baselines to avoid breaches.
“When you’ve got a pollution reduction policy that doesn’t reduce pollution, it’s time to start over,” he said.
Environment department data shows national emissions have risen each year since 2014. Under their current trajectory, the department projects emissions would be about 2% higher in 2030 than in 2005. The government’s target is a 26% to 28% cut over that time frame; Labor has proposed a 45% cut.
The Carbon Market Institute chief executive, Peter Castellas, said the safeguard mechanism data showed Australia clearly had a functioning carbon market that had been able to meet the demand of businesses that required credits.
It is understood most credits purchased were from surplus emissions cuts by companies that had won contracts under the emissions reduction. The carbon price spiked to as high as $18 a tonne – well beyond the average $11.90 under the emissions reduction fund – due to limited supply.
Castellas said industry had not been expected to breach the safeguard mechanism. Its operation augured well for a time when the demand for carbon credits increased.
“Safeguard mechanism baselines will inevitably have to decline if we are to meet below business as usual emissions required under Australia’s Paris agreement commitments,” he said.

Some of the more risky ideas like seeding the ocean with iron filings or putting out aerosols to reduce the impact of CO2 on solar radiation are also referred to as "geo-engineering".', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521549881000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'113792500', u'id': u'113793706', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'When my oldest grandson was three years old his girlfriend was Noah, beautiful blond curly haired Jewish girl.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521549850000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'113774198', u'id': u'113793675', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RupertGladstone', u'text': u'There seems to be some confusion here about what has actually been suggested. This Guardian article is about a Nature comment. I am one of the authors of the Nature comment, and I suggest that people read it. It isn’t very long, and might clear up some of the confusion. 
I want to clarify a few things now. I don’t plan to get into a debate here, everyone is welcome to their opinion, but I do want to avoid misunderstandings. This is my personal response – I am not representing my co-authors here.
We didn’t at any point in the comment suggest building a wall as a direct physical obstacle to hold back a glacier.
The Nature comment is edited but not peer-reviewed. This is because it presents ideas and opinions rather than scientific results. I think that it is worth carrying out further scientific studies to investigate the viability of these polar geo-engineering projects (indeed such research is already underway), and such studies WILL be peer reviewed before publication. The peer review process is not a 100% guarantee of accuracy but it certainly helps.
I don’t want to see these projects implemented. I would rather see hard mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions. I am glad to see that a lot of posters here want the same thing. But if such mitigation cannot be implemented (and this is the responsibility of policy makers not just scientists) then targeted geoengineering may be the lesser of two (or more) evils while emissions are brought down more gradually. I do not think that any kind of geoengineering should be viewed as a long term solution to human-induced climate change. I don’t know anyone who does.
We did not calculate the CO2 costs of the projects suggested in this Nature comment. Much research is needed before a decision can be made on any of these projects, including both scientific and engineering viability. Assessment of the CO2 impact of the project is one important aspect of this. It may be that some of the energy could be renewable, e.g. wind turbine driven water pumping.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521548340000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it presents ideas and opinions rather than scientific results', u'effect': u'this is'}], u'author_id': u'17040466', u'id': u'113792500', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'BQSTART

Which one?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521533513000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'113750965', u'id': u'113782490', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'20CharactersNoSpaces', u'text': u'Thanks for your reply, remainz - interesting ideas, these.Sadly I agree with your final sentence, and expect the consequences to be catastrophic for civilisation, and perhaps for our survival as a species.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521530135000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13730839', u'in_reply_to': u'113774527', u'id': u'113781436', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Cowan', u'text': u'Shading the ice with solar panels would reduce the albedo from maybe 0.8 to around 0.1, the same as open water.
