Temperature is a myth.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521521918000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13533153', u'in_reply_to': u'113774198', u'id': u'113779387', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Cowan', u'text': u'Thank you for your incisive, well reasoned contribution to the discussion.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521521847000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13533153', u'in_reply_to': u'113774451', u'id': u'113779368', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Cowan', u'text': u'It might be 2m by 2100 and 3m in 100 years. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2016/03/30/antarctic-loss-could-double-expected-sea-level-rise-by-2100-scientists-say/', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521521668000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13533153', u'in_reply_to': u'113775919', u'id': u'113779323', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Cowan', u'text': u'They would model the impacts for any project that was moving towards becoming reality. Such environmental risk assessments are pretty standard for major projects.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521521196000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13533153', u'in_reply_to': u'113749093', u'id': u'113779240', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Cowan', u'text': u'Unfortunately the web of connections between different aspects of the problem is quite difficult to grasp, some of the basic concepts are unfamiliar to most people (how many understand what an absorption spectrum chart means, I wonder?) and evil propagandists have encouraged people to sneer at what they don't understand and to grab on to simplistic and essentially stupid "proofs" that supposedly poke holes in the science - "climate's always changing", "the world's getting greener", "scientists want to take our money", etc. etc.We should be teaching climate change science in schools, so that young people are forewarned and well enough informed to demand necessary action.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521521012000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13533153', u'in_reply_to': u'113766985', u'id': u'113779196', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'I'd strongly encourage you to read the article I linked to above, because it addresses several of these claims.
- land temperature adjustments include just as many that decrease warming as those that increase it;
- land temperature adjustments increase the overall 1880-2016 warming trend by 16%, but ocean temperature adjustments have been in the other direction. When the two are combined, the global 1880-2016 adjusted data actually warm 20% less (!) than the raw data;
- the main reason for alterations to the adjustments over time is that much new data have become available. The number of historical land stations available has increased fivefold, and global coverage has improved.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521519797000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it addresses several of these claims', u'effect': u"i 'd strongly encourage you to read the article i linked to above"}], u'author_id': u'15902664', u'in_reply_to': u'113774683', u'id': u'113778935', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'I'm glad I don't live in the West.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521517086000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'113727029', u'id': u'113778369', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The Penguins Union is mobilizing against Donald.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521516653000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'113721265', u'id': u'113778268', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Alarmism is exaggerating a danger. The scientists reporting on the acceleration in the rate of sea level rise over the last 130 years are not exaggerating what they have discovered. Therefore they are not being alarmist.
You say that "Satellite measurements are at odds with tidal gauge measurements and that needs to be resolved".
Church and White's study is based on "satellite altimeter data from 1993 to 2009 and from coastal and island measurements from 1880 to 2009. For 1993 to 2009, after correcting for glacial isostatic adjustment, the estimated rate of rise is 3.2 + or - 0.4 mm per year from the satellite data and 2.8 + or - 0.8 mm per year from the in situ data."
"The Antarctic is gaining ice mass" on the 3,000 metre high East Antarctic Plateau because the warmer Southern Ocean is supplying more moisture. At the same time it is losing ice mass where its continental glaciers are grounded below sea level at depth and in contact with the that warmer Southern Ocean. The rate of ice mass loss is increasing faster than the rate of ice mass gain and is expected to exceed the latter in a few decades.
"Greenland gained ice this winter" as did New York but the glaciers aren't returning to the Hudson.
"Tropical islands like the Maldives, which are supposed to be sinking, have gained land area" as sediment deposition in some parts of coral cays can keep pace with an average sea level rise of 3.0 mm while it other parts of the same or different islands it doesn't.
"A recent paper found that in some places the sea bed is sinking under the increased weight of water above it due to sea level rise"
This hydro-isostacy was observed decades ago in Queensland in response to the flooding of the previously dry broad continental shelf (now the lagoon of the Great Barrier Reef) by the 130 metres of sea level at the end of the last glacial period.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521515585000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the warmer southern ocean is supplying more moisture', u'effect': u'the antarctic is gaining ice mass on'}, {u'cause': u'sea level rise', u'effect': u'that in some places the sea bed is sinking under the increased weight of water above it'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'113752457', u'id': u'113778013', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"The advance and retreat of glaciers is a natural cycle that takes places over centuries."
Over the last 2.6 million years largest scale advances and retreats of glaciers (glacial and interglacial periods) have occurred over 10,000s of years in response to orbital and axial oscillations or cycles. The last such major retreat occurrred between 19,000 and 9,000 years ago in response to a Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation (NHHLSI) peak which provoked the oxidation of carbon rich ocean sediments in the Southern Ocean causing global greenhouse warming. Natural processes are defined as those independent of human agency. As there was no human agency in the oxidation of those Southern Ocean sediments, the global greenhouse warming from 19,000 to 9,000 years ago was natural.
This natural deglacial warming resulted in a world at 9,000 ybp warmer than preindustrial centuries of the last millennium. This world stayed warm for another 4,000 years, then temperatures declined as NHHLSI declined resulting in the expansion of glaciers in recent millennia up until last century.
The very rapid warming and consequent current retreat of glaciers is caused by CO2 from the oxidation of coal and other fossil fuels by combustion which has involved human agency and is therefore not natural.
Many glaciers in retreat have revealed tree stumps of earlier forestation, screeds" (screes) "where they terminated in earlier times, and in a few cases human settlements".
The human settlements reflect the warmer times particularly before around 5,000 ybp as do the terminal and higher lateral moraine screes and evidence of a higher tree line.
"Sea level is not rising any faster than it was before according to tidal gauges."
Sea level was stable from 200 BC to 1000 AD, then rose at an average rate of 0.6 mm per year up to 1400 AD. It was stable again from 1400 AD to the late 19th century since then rose 210 mm from 1880 to 2009.
See Church and White (2011) "Sea Level Rise from the Late 19th to Early 21st Century" Surveys in Geophysics Volume 32 Issue 4-5 pp 585-602 September.
Note Figure 5 which shows the global mean sea level rise from the late 19th century to 2009.
The authors conclude as follows.
"The linear trend from 1900 to 2009 is 1.7 + or - 0.2 mm per year and since 1961 1.9 + or - 0.4 mm per year. There is no possibility of adaptation for the world population at this rate of warming.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521473369000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'113751842', u'id': u'113755422', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'derekcolman', u'text': u'This was a hoax paper written by a software program which makes sentences out of key words fed into it. The object of the exercise was to see if a nonsense paper could pass peer review and get published, which is indeed what happened to it. It is not unique. A number of similar nonsense papers, mostly in the field of medical science, have also passed peer review and got published. The object of the exercise was to show that peer review is broken, and is a completely useless at sorting the wheat from the chaff. One prominent medical scientist believes that up to 50% of published papers are bogus. There is no reason to believe that the same does not apply in climate science. Indeed one well known bogus paper, Karl et al 2015, not only passed peer review and got published, but has been vehemently praised and defended by a number of other alarmist scientist, despite a larger number of climate scientists decrying it and a whistleblower exposing it.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521458695000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2600028', u'in_reply_to': u'113737835', u'id': u'113741553', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521472270000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'113750965', u'id': u'113754569', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'The claim that climate scientists are engaged "massive data manipulation" doesn't stand up to scrutiny.
Raw data have to be adjusted for biases. Karl et al. (2015) is in fact a good example. It corrected the discrepancy between the old way of measuring ocean temperatures (engine room intakes) and the more recent data from buoys. This was important because the two methods give slightly different results.
Despite misinformed claims to the contrary, raw temperature data and adjustment methodologies are freely available, so anyone disputing the process can point out flaws in the statistical procedures or produce their own analysis. But they never do. 
In any event, the adjustments to the raw data are not actually very large, and you may be surprised to learn that over the long term they in fact decrease the total amount of warming.
This is a very useful short article on the subject, written by a scientist who contributed to a study with similar findings to Karl et al.

description: Underwater sea walls and artificial islands among projects urgently required to avoid devastation of global flooding, say scientists
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Underwater sea walls and artificial islands among projects urgently required to avoid devastation of global flooding, say scientists
og_fields.og:title: Billion-dollar polar engineering ‘needed to slow melting glaciers’
text:
Scientists have outlined plans to build a series of mammoth engineering projects in Greenland and Antarctica to help slow down the disintegration of the planet’s main glaciers. The controversial proposals include underwater walls, artificial islands and huge pumping stations that would channel cold water into the bases of glaciers to stop them from melting and sliding into the sea.
The researchers say the work – costing tens of billions of dollars a time – is urgently needed to prevent polar glaciers melting and raising sea levels. That would lead to major inundations of low-lying, densely populated areas, such as parts of Bangladesh, Japan and the Netherlands.
Flooding in these areas is likely to cost tens of trillions of dollars a year if global warming continues at its present rate, and vast sea-wall defences will need to be built to limit the devastation. Such costs make glacier engineering in polar regions a competitive alternative, according to the team, which is led by John Moore, professor of climate change at the University of Lapland.
“We think that geoengineering of glaciers could delay much of Greenland and Antarctica’s grounded ice from reaching the sea for centuries, buying time to address global warming,” the scientists write in the current issue of Nature. “Geoengineering of glaciers has received little attention in journals. Most people assume that it is unfeasible and environmentally undesirable. We disagree.”
Ideas put forward by the group specifically target the ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctic because these will contribute more to sea rise this century than any other source, they say. Their proposals include:
• Building a 100-metre high wall on the seabed across a 5km wide fjord at the end of the Jakobshavn glacier in western Greenland. This would reduce influxes of warming sea water which are eroding the glacier’s base;
• Constructing artificial islands in front of glaciers in Antarctica in order to buttress them and limit their collapse as their ice melts due to global warming;
• Circulating cooled brine underneath glaciers such as the Pine Island glacier in Antarctica – in order to prevent their bases from melting and sliding towards the sea.
In each case, the team – which includes scientists in Finland and the US – acknowledges that costs would be in the billions. Construction is also likely to cause considerable disruption. For example, building a dam across the Jakobshavn fjord could affect ecology, fisheries and tourism, and large numbers of workers would have to be shipped in to complete the project.
Similarly, building artificial islands in front of glaciers would mean importing about six cubic kilometres of material, a task that would be immensely difficult in stormy Antarctic waters. And drilling through ice that is kilometres thick to pump down cooled water would also stretch the capabilities of engineers.
However, the team insists that such projects should be carefully assessed now as the likely costs appear to be compatible with those of other large energy and civil engineering works being planned across the globe. The issue is simple, they state: should we spend vast sums to wall off all the world’s coasts, or can we address the problem at its source?
“Potential risks, especially to local ecosystems, need careful analysis,” they conclude. “In our view, however, the greatest risk is doing nothing.”

description: Green Alliance says ending UK sales earlier would close climate target gap and halve oil imports
og_fields.og:description: Green Alliance says ending UK sales earlier would close climate target gap and halve oil imports
og_fields.og:title: Ban new petrol and diesel cars in 2030, not 2040, says thinktank
text:
Ministers have been urged to bring forward their 2040 ban on new diesel and petrol car sales by a decade, a move which an environmental thinktank said would almost halve oil imports and largely close the gap in the UK’s climate targets.
The Green Alliance said a more ambitious deadline of 2030 is also needed to avoid the UK squandering its leadership on electric cars.
While the number of electric cars being sold in the UK has rocketed in the past four years, Germany overtook the UK last year in its rise in the registrations of new plug-in hybrids and 100% battery-powered cars. A 2030 ban on combustion engine models would boost sales of electrified cars in the UK and even raise the prospect of the country becoming an net vehicle exporter, the Green Alliance said.
While the UK lags behind Germany on conventional car manufacturing, a fifth of the electric cars sold in Europe in 2016 were made at Nissan’s Sunderland plant in north-east England. BMW has pledged to make its electric Mini at its plant in Oxford, but UK-headquartered Jaguar Land Rover chose to build its first flagship electric car, the i-Pace, in Austria.
Dustin Benton, policy director at Green Alliance, said: “The government’s recent industrial strategy cites clean growth as one of the biggest economic opportunities for the UK, but if we keep building and buying dirty cars we’ll miss the growth opportunity of the century.”
The transport sector overtook energy in 2016 as the UK’s single biggest source of carbon emissions, as power generation has switched away from coal and towards renewables.
Carbon emissions from the average new car also rose last year for the first time in nearly two decades, as drivers opted for bigger models.
The Green Alliance found that an earlier phase-out for new diesels and petrol cars would affect the looming gap in the UK’s legally binding 2030 climate target. A 2030 deadline would cut the gap by 85%, or 98 million tonnes CO2e.
Sticking with a 2040 date would also lead to fossil-fuelled cars causing air pollution until the second half of the century, the thinktank said, given the average UK car is scrapped after 14 years. Four committees of MPs last week warned that air pollution is a “national health emergency” and called on the government to take tougher action.
Earlier action would also ease the UK’s reliance on oil imports at a time when oil and gas production from the North Sea is declining. Imports would be cut by nearly 50% by 2035, saving up to an estimated £6.63bn each year, the thinktank said.
While ministers last summer followed France by pledging to halt new petrol and diesel car sales by 2040, other countries are looking to ban them years earlier. Scotland is aiming for 2032, India wants to only sell electric models by 2030 and Norway, the world leader on the take-up of battery-powered cars, has set a 2025 deadline.
The Green Alliance said the government could take several other measures to sustain the UK’s leadership on electric cars, including public procurement. A grant of up to £4,500 to buyers of electric cars should also be extended, the group said, and government could further help by setting manufacturers sales targets for electric cars, starting at 15% of all cars sold in 2022 and rising to 45% by 2025.
The car industry body, the SMMT, said outright bans on petrol and diesels risked harming the new car market, and the sector could be undermined if not given enough time to adjust.

description: Tens of millions in three regions of the developing world expected to migrate before 2050 unless environment is improved
og_fields.og:description: Tens of millions in three regions of the developing world expected to migrate before 2050 unless environment is improved
og_fields.og:title: Climate change soon to cause movement of 140m people, World Bank warns
text:
Climate change will result in a massive movement of people inside countries and across borders, creating “hotspots” where tens of millions pour into already crowded slums, according to the World Bank.
More than 140 million people in just three regions of the developing world are likely to migrate within their native countries between now and 2050, the first report on the subject has found. 
The World Bank examined three regions, which between them account for 55% of the developing world’s population. In sub-Saharan Africa, 86 million are expected to be internally displaced over the period; in south Asia, about 40 million; and in Latin America, 17 million.
Such flows of people could cause enormous disruption, threatening governance and economic and social development, but the World Bank cautioned that it was still possible to stave off the worst effects.
“Climate change-driven migration will be a reality, but it does not need to be a crisis, provided we take action now and act boldly,” said John Roome, a senior director for climate change at the World Bank group.
He laid out three key actions governments should take: first, to accelerate their reductions of greenhouse gases; second, for national governments to incorporate climate change migration into their national development planning; and third, to invest in further data and analysis for use in planning development.
Within countries, the effects of climate change will create multiple “hotspots”: made up of the areas people move away from in large numbers, and the areas they move to.
“Local planners need to make sure the resources are made available, and to make sure it takes place in a comprehensive and coordinated manner,” said Roome.
Globally, many tens of millions more are expected to be similarly affected, creating huge problems for national and local governments. Nearly 3% of the population was judged likely to move owing to climate change in the areas studied – a proportion that might be repeated elsewhere.
Migration between countries has previously taken the spotlight, with its potential for cross-border conflicts, but internal migration may cause as much disruption, putting pressure on infrastructure, jobs, food and water resources.
The 140 million figure extrapolates from current trends, but could be reduced if changes are made. If economic development is made more inclusive, for instance through better education and infrastructure, internal migration across the three regions could drop to between 65 million and 105 million, according to the report. If strong action is taken on greenhouse gas emissions, as few as 30 million to 70 million may migrate.
Climate change is likely to most affect the poorest and most vulnerable, making agriculture difficult or even impossible across large swaths of the globe, threatening water resources and increasing the likelihood of floods, droughts and heatwaves in some areas. Sea level rises and violent storm surges are also likely to hit low-lying coastal areas, such as in Bangladesh.
Kristalina Georgieva, the chief executive of the World Bank, in her introduction to the report published on Monday, said: “There is growing recognition among researchers that more people will move within national borders to escape the effects of slow-onset climate change, such as droughts, crop failure and rising seas. 
“The number of climate migrants could be reduced by tens of millions as a result of global action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and with far-sighted development planning. There is an opportunity now to plan and act for emerging climate change threats.”

description: Instability attributed to changes in power mix that can leave grid at mercy of the weather
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Instability attributed to changes in power mix that can leave grid at mercy of the weather
og_fields.og:title: Energy market commission says electricity grid increasingly unstable
text:
The Australian Energy Market Commission says the national electricity grid is becoming more unstable, with 11 incidents in 2016-17, up from seven the year before and four the year before that.
The instability is attributed to changes in the power generation mix, with thermal, synchronous generators leaving the system in favour of more renewable capacity, which can leave the grid at the mercy of the weather.
The new assessment from the AEMC released on Tuesday comes as the Turnbull government’s prospects of securing agreement for its national energy guarantee have improved courtesy of Jay Weatherill’s departure as the South Australian premier after Saturday’s state election.
Weatherill led the resistance at the state level to the Turnbull proposal, which is supposed to address some of the problems in Australia’s electricity network by imposing new reliability and emissions reduction guarantees on energy retailers and large energy users from 2020.
The Energy Security Board is currently leading consultations with a range of stakeholders about the design of the policy, which will be considered next by federal and state energy ministers on 20 April.
While the Turnbull government has proposed the national energy guarantee as a mechanism to end the decade-long climate wars, the proposal remains contentious with stakeholders, including environment groups and analysts who argue it won’t deliver the scale of emissions reductions to ensure Australia conforms with our commitments under the Paris agreement.
New modelling from market analysts Reputex released on Monday also suggests the Turnbull government’s emissions reduction target for the electricity sector will be met thanks to state renewable energy targets – effectively rendering the federal proposal redundant in climate terms.
The AEMC has meanwhile released new reports taking stock of the reliability of the electricity system. It says system security issues have arisen as a consequence of less synchronous generation in the system and changes in the way generating units are being operated.
It says there has been a reduction in primary frequency control and associated degradation of the frequency distribution – which has implications across the grid.
The report notes that “over the last few years there has been a decreasing level of system inertia due to the withdrawal of synchronous thermal generation and increased penetration of non-synchronous generation” – a development that can “result in the failure of load or generation”.
The report says there were 11 incidents in 2016-17, including the statewide power blackout in South Australia. 
It says the frequency operating standard was met for the mainland over the course of the year but the frequency operating standard was not met for Tasmania for seven months of the 2016/17 financial year.

Yes, some do regrow after fires and some require fire to release seeds but equally, there are large areas of Australian bushlands, examples would include the famed "Gondwana remnants" along the mainland East Coast and into Tasmania that fire events will kill. A section of the Tasmanian forest burned in a bush fire consuming vegetation over 1000 years old and so, irreplaceable.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521705915000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15055115', u'in_reply_to': u'113784349', u'id': u'113864459', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'What's the Carnarvon catchment? The fruit growing town of Carnarvon is located at the mouth of the Gascoyne River 100 km north of the two arms of Shark Bay. No major rivers flow into Shark Bay which is why the eastern arm, due to the reduced tidal interchange produced by the sea grass covered Faure Sill, is so saline that only one species of bivalve lives in its waters, oolites precipitate out when waves break and blue green bacterial mats produce cryptalgal limestones in situ plus stromatolites. Most of the sea grass grows in the western arm which is also where most of boating and recreational fishing occurs. Apart from the paucity of fish, much of the eastern arm has hard ground in situ limestone cemented bottoms unsuitable for anchorage.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521676969000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the reduced tidal interchange produced by the sea grass', u'effect': u'why the eastern arm covered faure sill'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'113830942', u'id': u'113859162', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'In considering global warming and climate change, everybody knows there are other problems besides CO2 emissions from fossil fuels, such as "Change in Land Use". It's unlikely scientists know less than everybody else...', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521643934000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'113830942', u'id': u'113841087', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'It makes me want to spit nails. I long ago gave up seafood. It is time to leave the ocean alone!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521642077000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15758543', u'in_reply_to': u'113800747', u'id': u'113839747', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'Minor point: We don't have any effect on total water vapor in the air because it self regulates, but burning hydrocarbons creates water vapor just as it creates co2.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521641641000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it self regulates', u'effect': u"minor point we do n't have any effect on total water vapor in the air but burning hydrocarbons creates water vapor just as it creates co2"}], u'author_id': u'15758543', u'in_reply_to': u'113822945', u'id': u'113839411', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Lawrie Griffith', u'text': u'I think you may have misunderstood my post. (I hope I haven't misunderstood yours.)
As I said in my first response:The 'managerialist' response is not my view.I was simply scoping what the managerialist position looks like so it could be critiqued.I was not advocating it. Sorry if I gave that impression.
Much discussion seems to focus on the deniers. (Whose position is untenable, and who probably can't be reasoned with.)I was merely pointing out that 'managerialism' is another barrier to action on climate change. It is a potentially greater barrier to action because it is superficially more plausible to gung-ho business people.Managerialism doesn't deny the fact of climate change. But it claims it is a problem that can just be managed away at some future date. (Which it almost certainly can't.) In that sense, managerialism is a greater barrier to action now, because it is an excuse for the corporate world to carry on business as usual.
To quote myself above:'I think the great flaw in managerialism is that it ignores the cascading and multiplication effects of tipping points and feedback loops.'
My post was about trying to scope forms of resistance to action on climate change, other than just dumb denial. In this case 'managerialism', so the debate could offer arguments to overcome the managerialist excuse.
I hope that clears that up. Cheers.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521636224000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it is superficially more plausible to gung ho people', u'effect': u'it is a potentially greater barrier to action'}, {u'cause': u'it is an excuse for the corporate world to carry on business as usual', u'effect': u'in that sense managerialism is a greater barrier to action now'}], u'author_id': u'13793892', u'in_reply_to': u'113828113', u'id': u'113834810', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ClareLondon', u'text': u'If you put cold water into a kettle and turn on the switch, it will at least a minute to come to the boil, won't it? Modern, powerful kettles will. How about if you took a huge saucepan instead, one as large as your cooker, filled that with cold water, put a lid on and turned on the gas. That would take at least 5 minutes, if not 10 or 15, to heat up until steam was coming out. An enormous VAT the size of a room filled with cold water would probably take at least a day, from cold, to heat to boiling. 
The above describes 'lag' or 'latency'.
Now imagine the climate system, where there is anything from 20 - 50 years lag between EMISSIONS and WARMING. Fact. The climate response we've seen, the warming we've seen, is as a response to emissions from the last couple of hundred years up to about 50 years ago. Or, if we're very lucky, only 20 years ago.
But over the last 50 years and certainly over the last 20 years emissions haven't crashed to barely anything. They're risen inexorably over the timeframe. 
So, if the record temperatures we've seen are as a response to historic emissions and not to what we've put into the atmosphere over the last few decades, and if as a result of those historic emissions the arctic is mush, we're seeing sea levels rising, the seas are acidified, there is increased flooding, huge increase in drought and wildfire, appalling bleaching of coral reefs and ever more catastrophic hurricanes - but that's all without what we've put into the atmosphere over the last few decades, what kind of state do you think the climate will be in in 50 years' time? Given the feedback systems? 
(Feedback systems being one thing that triggers another, as in, as the oceans warm, metahne is released from the deep seat bed, which createws further warming, which releases more methane, in a cycle which gradually intensified and speeds up.And there are many others.
A few years ago in India temperatures rose so high (over 40C degrees) that people could not touch surfaces without blistering their hands. You took so calmly about 'adaption', 'coping', 'resilience'. But what about when temperatures reach 50C in India - ? The population won't survive that. Higher still and people will boil alive if they go outside.
These temperature rises are not survivable. 
The mistake you're making, as so many do, is to imagine that global warming is linear and will increase ever so gradually and gently over several decades. That gradually the temperatures will rise, like a barometer in the summer as the day advances in to the afternoon from the cooler morning. That is slightly what is happening now, today, NOW. But when the trigger points are reached, and warming goes out of control, and the exponential effect kicks in, temperatures will soar. Very very fast. Who knows how fast? If you think back to Sunday, when temperatures were minus 0 across the country, but by the next day were several degrees warmer - who's to say that a rise from 40C to 50C to 60C or higher won't happen almost overnight? I hope it doesn't, but who's to say it won't?
Which leaves me very frightened. Not 'pessimistic' - just bloody terrified. You, not so much. So - reach the literature, listen to talks, watch the slides, understand the science. 
Then try to work with others to get politicians to act.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521634550000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1372819', u'in_reply_to': u'113823140', u'id': u'113833223', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ClareLondon', u'text': u'BQSTART
I don't share this particular aspect of your pessimism.
BQEND
But you're completely missing the point. You're shutting down the science and instead defaulting to talking about my emotional state. As if it's all down to my pessimism rather than the science. Putting it down to 'pessimism' is neither here nor there. Out of control global warming will take place at certain trigger points regardless of whether I'm 'pessimistic', 'happy', 'angry', 'miserable', 'deliriously happy' or any other emotional state I might happen to be in.  
BQSTART
I do believe that we humans are in for a terrible time collectively, and a great deal of innocent flora and fauna will be collateral damage. But I have worked for 35 years in IT related industries
BQEND
But, begging your pardon, this is ridiculous. You can't compare the cliamte system and atmosphere to your knowledge of computers. I know about computers, too. I have written software in the past, too. What's know about system design in computers got to do with it? I could talk about my intricate knowledge of the m mechanics of vacuum clceaners, or jet engines, or suspension bridges and it still won't have a damned thing to do with the climate system. I wouldn't rest on your laurels in that regard, if I were you.
As for the internet system design, again, that's totally irrelevant. The climate isn't a series of zeros and ones. It's a vast, interconnected, planetary climate system taking in the oceans and the air and plant life and trapped methane and CO2 emissions - it's not a linear system, it doesn't rely on linear calculations (which computer calculations are).
Global warming is not a lineart system. Warming an exponential system. The warmer it gets, the more quickly it will get hotter still. As you can infer directly from this article, if you understand what you're reading. (That is not meant to be rude.)
BQSTART
my understanding of these systems gives me hope that we will lose far less than you might think.
BQEND
Oh but excuse me, gpwayne. I'm not a climate scientist. It's not what I think. You mistunderstand me completely. It's about what the world's climate scientists 'think'. And actually it isn't about what people 'think' or 'believe'. It's about hard science, facts, not 'thinking' things and 'believing' things. 
Fact. Your idea of resilience is essentially - and forgive me for saying so, again, I'm not trying to be rude - male arrogance. Your idea is that you can do anything, solve anything, you have the technical ability. Because you think you do.
But you don't. Because, as I've said a trillion times on this site, please tell me how, last summer, you could have used your male expertise to stop one of the Atlantic hurricanes in its tracks. Or stop a tsunami. Or stop a wildfire.
Temperatures will soar with global warming and the more they soar the faster they will soar, because of all the feedback mechanisms in place. Computer systems, the internet, do not have exponential qualities and they do not have feedback systems in the way the climate system does. They are linear systems, producing a result at the end of a string of noughts and ones. Even if the strings are millions of characters long, they are still linear systems.
The key fact you have not taken from what I wrote - and nobody ever does, is this: (oh - and this isn't 'thinking', it's not 'my' idea - it's hard science.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521634511000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'all the feedback mechanisms in place', u'effect': u'they soar the faster they will soar'}], u'author_id': u'1372819', u'in_reply_to': u'113823140', u'id': u'113833179', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'philipl', u'text': u'Well my complaint is about people who argue damage done without evidence. Provide it, I say, rather than presume it as fact.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521631754000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16394723', u'in_reply_to': u'113811131', u'id': u'113831163', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jhoptoad', u'text': u'BQSTART

It is a fact, established by basic physics and mountains of hard evidence.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521631738000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10189992', u'in_reply_to': u'113822381', u'id': u'113831145', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'woobble', u'text': u'Why no mention of the huge land clearance in the Carnarvon catchment that drains into Sharks Bay? The seagrass mortality in 2011 is also closely linked to the massive flooding of the rivers, flooding that was exacerbated by the fact that half the drainage basin has been cleared for ranching, leading to massive sediment runoff. Seagrass depends on clear water, so the die-off is at least in significant part due to land-use changes in the Carnarvon, and not just warm seas.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521631466000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'half the drainage basin', u'effect': u'massive sediment runoff'}, {u'cause': u'land use changes in the carnarvon', u'effect': u'the die off is'}], u'author_id': u'3585344', u'id': u'113830942', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AlanAinBerlin', u'text': u'BQSTART
Absolutely zero proof that such heatwaves did not lead to recovery of the seagrass after they ended
BQEND
I note that in your criticism you're omitting the most important part of the article - the sequestered gas. I know sequestered is a big word but try to follow the bit about the "carbon bomb" - it's in the first paragraph, so it shouldn't be too difficult to find.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521628822000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3814773', u'in_reply_to': u'113782045', u'id': u'113828741', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Your link is about sea ice not ice sheets.
It's quite important to know the differences between the various parts of the cryosphere.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521628640000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'113822443', u'id': u'113828600', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dave Boro', u'text': u'A sad but true observation. I also thought it sad how buried this article is. They are reporting such an incredible quantity of CO2 being released as a positive feedback that this should really be front page news.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521628481000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17962519', u'in_reply_to': u'113792475', u'id': u'113828471', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'BQSTART
Assumes that: -There is a problem.
BQEND
Not one professional scientific organisation on Earth says there isn't a problem.
You've got plenty of cranks of course, and conspiracy theorists.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521628243000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'113822381', u'id': u'113828273', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dave Boro', u'text': u'Sorry Lawrie but I am afraid I cannot agree - although it was refreshing to read a respectfully written response. "We can't crash the economy in a panicked response. " Where is the proof that the changes necessary will crash the economy. Deniers yell and scream at other for being "alarmists" but at the core of denial is alarmism that the changes to decarbonise the world economy will "destroy the economy" or "destroy capitalism and replace it with communism". Changing to a decarbonised world is simply redirecting investments - and the returns are good. Paul Hawkin's book Drawdown has analysed and ranked many of the current technology solutions along with their returns on investment.
But what is absolutely clear - lack of action will be expensive - very, very expensive. Failure to act poses a much greater risk to the world economy - not to mention political stability. The sooner and faster we act, the smaller these ultimate costs will be. If the bathroom upstairs is dripping water onto the ceiling below, you can fix it immediately or you can wait until the whole ceiling needs to be replaced - the cost to fix the leak is the same, but the overall cost is much greater when you fail to act quickly. Every extra bit of CO2 we add to the air today is going to be there for hundreds or thousands of years. 
There is no time to wait - every day we wait we clock up a bigger bill of impacts.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521628069000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17962519', u'in_reply_to': u'113820583', u'id': u'113828113', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dave Boro', u'text': u'Sorry if I seem a tad condescending in my last post but the old denier's "ice is growing" claim is totally, utterly demonstrably wrong and extremely tiresome and infuriating.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521626363000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17962519', u'in_reply_to': u'113822443', u'id': u'113826596', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dave Boro', u'text': u'NASA have a serious of pretty pictures of the Arctic sea ice take from satellites over the years. You should have a look at them - you don't have to read any difficult sciency stuff, so it should be OK for a Breitbart reader. If you can't see the bleeding obvious trend, try asking a small child to help you analyse them.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521625955000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17962519', u'in_reply_to': u'113822443', u'id': u'113826252', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'B1ngoCrepuscule', u'text': u'Yeah. http://nsidc.org/data/seaice_index', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521621962000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4507134', u'in_reply_to': u'113781690', u'id': u'113823568', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'Arctic ice is at record lows and Antarctic second lowest but you have to can be forgiven for your ignorance as you appear to be getting your information from Breitbart.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521621769000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'113822443', u'id': u'113823501', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gpwayne', u'text': u'Thanks for your reply Clare.
BQSTART
The grief of thousands of years of human history which will be lost to the waves, the drought, the fire, knocks my brain about.
BQEND
I don't share this particular aspect of your pessimism. I do believe that we humans are in for a terrible time collectively, and a great deal of innocent flora and fauna will be collateral damage. But I have worked for 35 years in IT related industries, and my understanding of these systems gives me hope that we will lose far less than you might think.
My reasoning is based on the original designs for a resilient network system, designed by ARPA to mitigate against the disruption to communications brought about by nuclear war. The idea was to provide many redundant centres through which information could travel and be stored - what we now call the internet.
It is this remarkable resilience that leads me to believe the culture that you and I so value will survive, because our knowledge - science, the arts, technology - is stored in so many places that it's probably impossible to eliminate it all. Our achievements may well survive, even though very few of us will be around to benefit from it.
Anyway, that's my opinion - and I'm sticking to it (not that it does me a lot of good, but it's better than nothing).', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521620831000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"our knowledge science is stored in so many places that it 's probably impossible to eliminate it all", u'effect': u'the culture that you and i so value will survive'}], u'author_id': u'2947466', u'in_reply_to': u'113796573', u'id': u'113823140', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'There is a problem now and it's going to get much worse. The faster GHG emissions are reduced the better the outcome.We will want to remove CO2 from the atmosphere.
That be the view of reality based on the science.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521620289000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'113822381', u'id': u'113822952', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gpwayne', u'text': u'I don't believe you understood the point i was making, so I'll reframe my remarks. 
Note first of all that I started my comment by enumerating "The principle greenhouse gases contributing to climate change..." - of which CO2 is the most prevalent. I then pointed out that water vapour does not "contribute to climate change" which is why I left it out of the list of contributory causes.
Put in scientific terms, I'm talking about forcings - sources of energy that induce change. Increases in atmospheric greenhouse gases like CO2 and methane trap additional energy in the environment. Water vapour does not - there can be no increase in water vapour in advance of temperature rises, only afterwards. Water vapour is uneven in distribution, unlike CO2e gases; cold places are very dry, hot places very humid, and neither effect can be considered 'global'.
Water vapour also cannot be described as anthropogenic; we do not emit, directly cause or increase water vapour (except in very small local events like power station cooling towers). 
So - CO2, methane et. al. cause global warming. Water vapour doesn't, but it does play a major part in retaining the heat once it's in the atmosphere or oceans.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521620272000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'al', u'effect': u'global warming'}], u'author_id': u'2947466', u'in_reply_to': u'113814979', u'id': u'113822945', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BillSoko', u'text': u'there are some who deny everything including their own existence ........ evolution of H sapiens has not been very even.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521619735000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18386839', u'in_reply_to': u'113811865', u'id': u'113822734', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BillSoko', u'text': u'yep, another opportunity to 'capitalize' on ..... don't stress; WE will now fix the problem we caused but YOU went along with ... well, were paid you to come for the ride... DON'T try to tell US how to fix the problem.... didn't you and your kids watch Mickey Mouse..?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521619129000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'18386839', u'in_reply_to': u'113795285', u'id': u'113822508', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anteaus', u'text': u'http://www.breitbart.com/big-government/2018/03/12/delingpole-more-climate-scientists-rescued-from-polar-ice-this-could-be-a-major-trend/

People are pretty resourceful when they have to be so even if the next 20 years go badly (and they clearly aren't going to go very well - it's a bit late for that), so long as total war can be avoided, I don't think the risk of collapse is very high over that timescale.There is an element of 'don't frighten the horses' as explained by Kevin Anderson when he talks about the inclusion of large negative emissions into the modelling in order to produce a 'politicallly acceptable' result.
