description: Dana Nuccitelli: Ultimately the only thing that matters: we need to cut carbon pollution as much as possible, as fast as possible
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Ultimately the only thing that matters: we need to cut carbon pollution as much as possible, as fast as possible
og_fields.og:title: Climate scientists debate a flaw in the Paris climate agreement | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
In September 2017, a team led by the University of Exeter’s Richard Millar published a paper in Nature Geoscience, which was widely reported as suggesting that the Paris climate agreement’s aspirational goal of limiting global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial temperatures is still technically within our reach. Many other climate scientists were skeptical of this result, and the journal recently published a critique from a team led by the University of Edinburgh’s Andrew Schurer.
The debate lies in exactly how the Paris climate target is defined and measured, which has not been precisely established. Millar’s team used the UK Met Office and Hadley Centre global surface temperature dataset called HadCRUT4, which begins in 1850 and estimates global surface temperatures have warmed about 0.9°C since that time. The team thus calculated the remaining carbon budget that will lead to an additional 0.6°C warming.
But HadCRUT4 has some significant flaws. First, it only covers 84% of Earth’s surface. There are large gaps in its coverage, mainly in the Arctic, Antarctica, and Africa, where temperature monitoring stations are relatively scarce. And the Arctic is the fastest-warming part of the planet, which means that HadCRUT4 somewhat underestimates global warming.
A second issue is that over the oceans, HadCRUT4 uses sea surface temperatures, which haven’t warmed quite as fast as air temperatures directly above the ocean surface. There’s also a third issue – what’s the start date from which we want to stay below 1.5 or 2°C warming? The starting point in HadCRUT4 is 1850, but another recent study led by Schurer found that starting even earlier would add up to 0.2°C to the warming we’ve already caused, and thus shrink the remaining carbon budget.
Taken all together, these three issues could mean that we’ve already warmed 0.2–0.3°C more than estimated in the Millar study, which would mean a significantly smaller carbon budget. Each additional 0.1°C warming shrinks the remaining 2°C carbon budget by about 20%, so in that sense even one-tenth of a degree is important in answering this question about our chances of meeting the Paris targets.
Ultimately, climate scientists are asking for a more specific definition of the Paris climate target. The agreement says we want to limit global warming to no more than 2°C above pre-industrial levels (preferably closer to 1.5°C), but when is the post-industrial start date, and which temperature measurement is the target based on?
However, the 2°C target itself is somewhat arbitrary. It’s based on two factors: science and politics. On the scientific side, we can probably accept and adapt to the adverse climate change consequences at that degree of climate change. On the political side, transitioning away from a fossil fuel-based global economy is a tremendous undertaking. From a practical standpoint, it will take everything we’ve got just to stay below 2°C. That’s why the 1.5°C target in the Paris agreement is ‘aspirational.’ The latest IPCC report considered 116 potential scenarios for staying below 2°C, and 101 of those scenarios (87%) included negative emissions in the form of carbon capture and storage. In other words, it’s difficult to envision meeting the Paris target by cutting carbon pollution alone.
The 2°C target is simply a nice round number that represents what the international community considers an acceptable amount of climate change risk and is also a practically achievable (although daunting) goal.
Tackling climate change boils down to risk management. Global temperatures are likely already hotter than at any time in the history of human civilization, and warming at a rate 20 to 50 times faster than Earth’s fastest natural climate changes. Climate contrarians like Trump’s EPA administrator Scott Pruitt often ask what’s Earth’s ideal temperature – the answer is that an ideal climate is a stable one. Rapid climate changes like the one humans are currently causing create problems that are difficult for species to adapt to. We need to shift away from dangerously rapid climate change to a stable climate as soon as possible.
The ideal Paris target would thus have simply been “cut carbon pollution as much as possible, as fast as possible.” However, governments need a concrete target on which to base their climate policies. “As much and as fast as possible” is vague and subjective, while “an 80% carbon pollution cut by 2050” is concrete, specific, and translates into policy.
The scientific debate over these few tenths of a degree of warming is in some ways important and in other ways unimportant. It’s unimportant because climate scientists are trying to assess our chances of meeting the Paris targets, but the 2°C itself is somewhat arbitrary. However, the Paris targets are important because they provide a concrete goal that governments and policies can aim for. And each additional tenth of a degree represents a greater risk that we’ll trigger a dangerous climate feedback, like a large release of methane from beneath the permafrost or oceans, or the collapse of a major ice shelf.
Thanks Chris. Policy implications not so big, imho. Whoever is right, in either case we need to hit the brakes on CO2 emissions as fast as we can. If the optimist study is right we might stop warming at 1.5 °C, if not the best we can hope for is ~2 °C, and coral reefs are gone.
The one point to take away from this debate is that no matter who’s right, we still need to cut carbon pollution as much as possible, as fast as possible. Using the choices in the Millar paper would suggest that we have a better chance of successfully meeting the Paris target, but even if the international community decides they like those choices best, it will still take everything we’ve got to stay below that definition of 2°C warming. 
If governments decide that based on the Millar paper they have a larger carbon budget and can thus afford to act less quickly, that would be an incorrect and dangerous interpretation. Climate policies need to keep progressing and improving at full steam ahead.

Pollutants can be artificial substances, such as pesticides and PCBs, or naturally occurring substances, such as oil or carbon dioxide, that occur in harmful concentrations in a given environment."', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522361086000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'114175180', u'id': u'114175308', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KurtinSwitzerland', u'text': u'P.S. I use the word "pollutants" here with a grain of salt. 
CO2 is not a pollutant per my definition. Sulfur dioxide, ash, (and yes, NOx) are indeed pollutants.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522360704000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16112781', u'in_reply_to': u'114175155', u'id': u'114175180', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KurtinSwitzerland', u'text': u'Modern turbo-diesel engines obtain better fuel economy than petrol (gasoline) engines. Since the goal of policy-makers was essentially to reduce CO2 emissions above all else, there was a wink of the eye wrt diesel's other pollutants, such as NOx. 
Diesel fuel is approx. 16% denser than petrol (it is heavier). Diesel fuel has approx. 10% greater energy density than petrol (per unit volume). Diesel fuel has approx. 5% LOWER specific energy than petrol (per unit mass). 
Diesel engines are fine. They power ships, trucks and power plants all over the globe.The demonization of Diesel motors and of VW is absurd. But perhaps the lower tax rate on Diesel might be worthy of reconsidering.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522360617000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16112781', u'in_reply_to': u'114174477', u'id': u'114175155', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mary1952', u'text': u'Thank you - interesting.

u'text': u'Sounds like we need an EV semi, perhaps one whose additional cost is paid back in 18 months from fuel savings, and can do 300-500 miles per charge.
Better still one with 4 standard car motors, allowing for extra torque, anti-jackknife torque steer, simple switching and industry scale cost savings. Plus the ability to 'pull like a diesel' even if two motors fail, so it can be sold with a one million mile no breakdown guarantee.
If only somebody could build one.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522494387000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'114203686', u'id': u'114213915', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'woobble', u'text': u'300 parts per million = life-sustaining, 400 parts per million = harmful....', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522490825000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3585344', u'in_reply_to': u'114175308', u'id': u'114212207', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'Hiya. Nothing to do with rust at all since we are still only talking about 3 to 6yrs of use.
An autonomous taxi will do a lot of miles, perhaps 100k per year. An ICE is generally good for about 150-200k miles before the engine/drivetrain maintenance will be too costly.
Current EV's should be good for 500k miles, possibly 1m miles soon.
So the capital cost of the taxi journey will hopefully be reduced by about 2/3rds.
So let's say the cost breakdown is 50% driver, 30% mileage costs (fuel, wear and tear/ maintenance), and 20% capital cost. Eliminate the driver, save 50%, reduce mileage cost by 90% v's an ICE, save 27%, and the investment (car) last 3x longer, save 13%.
Total saving approx 90% of old taxi fare.
Best thing is to watch one of the Tony Seba presentations as he sets it all out in detail, and he does have an excellent track record in predicting technology disruptions.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522481265000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'114196390', u'id': u'114208635', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChrisGordon1', u'text': u'I see where you are coming from but you cant legislate for lifestyle.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522475228000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16261177', u'in_reply_to': u'114179166', u'id': u'114207542', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Beekeeper49', u'text': u'I don't know about the situation in the UK, but in Australia diesel vehicles are often large four-wheel drive cars designed initially for travelling on rural back-roads that have not been surfaced with bitumem. Yet suburban mums drive them every day to shops and schools. They especially spew pollution when the driver initially sets off on a journey. The impact of diesel trucks in tunnels on our motorways creates so much pollution that the fumes released into the atmosphere near the tunnel entrances is very harmful to nearby residents.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522459541000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14883613', u'id': u'114205759', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mariner70', u'text': u'No, though I will admit that the CA bar on passenger Diesels came in at the same time as catalytic converters (and the shift to unleaded petrol) in the state. Guess I should have expanded a bit, so:
#2 Diesel (properly #2 Heating Oil) has a higher heat value than petrol. Combustion of one results in more heat energy than combustion of the other in the same quantity, with fewer combustion by-products generated by the reaction. _However_, while #2 Diesel emissions are lower, they're more toxic and harder to remove. The newer passenger (and commercial) Diesels in the US also use catalytic systems; it's taken until less than 10 years ago to get them small enough to fit in a relatively small vehicle and meet current emissions standards.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522455363000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'combustion of', u'effect': u'more heat energy than combustion of the other'}], u'author_id': u'10950170', u'in_reply_to': u'114180707', u'id': u'114205136', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GeraldLandry', u'text': u'You should do some serious math.  legislation presently in force makes it illegal to remove an existing DPF mechanism from a vehicle on a public road', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522413706000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100043529', u'in_reply_to': u'114184850', u'id': u'114189958', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Grandeemike', u'text': u'Crude oil is fractionated and the various streams are taken off the column and so you could say that that the lighter ends (naphtha, in the overheads for making petrol) will require more heat than the heavier gas oils taken off lower down the column as the lighter ends are vaporised more so more latent heat used. BUT the heat into the column is governed by its operation and the composition of the crude oil. Bear in mind around 40% of most crudes are bitumen and used on roads as well as further processed.
HOWEVER the thing about the gas oil taken off to be blended into diesel is that to remove the H2S and other impurities to make Ultra Low Sulphur Diesel is that ALL the gas oil stream is vaporised and put throught a Desulphur unit, then condensed. But most of the heat is recovered (depending on losses and efficiencies) so not really a consideration.
Reference filters, fine if they work and will collect a portion not 100% and NOx removal by Adblue may not be effective 100% e.g. when engine is cold.
There has been impressive improvements in petrol consumption now and not far off diesel figures, without all the diesel problems. Cost wise unless you do >15k miles per year a lot of petrol cars are much cheaper based on capital cost and fuel cost. Should discourage high mileage car use.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522404176000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14506387', u'in_reply_to': u'114175543', All the best. ;-)', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522394689000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'114175734', u'id': u'114182071', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'It's all about the money, and possibly convenience too.
The idea is that TaaS in the future will be about 90% cheaper than a taxi is today, since it'll remove the driver, reduce mileage costs by about 90% (EV v's ICE) and will last 3x as many miles, so cut the capital cost side by 2/3rds.
If a £10 taxi journey becomes £1, will people still want their own car, and the hassle and cost of parking at the destination?
At the very least, will households be able to justify the huge cost of having a second, third, fourth ... car sitting in their driveway 'just in case' costing them depreciation, tax, insurance maintenance etc..
Expect the 'youth' to lead the way, saving the cost and hassle of learning to drive.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522394527000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'114177928', u'id': u'114182030', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Andrew Cree', u'text': u'Yeah, let's ignore the fact that not all petrol engines are squeaky-clean when it comes to all emissions either shall we?

When I see a young man in a sports car, my first assumption is that he lives with his parents.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522376802000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1345293', u'in_reply_to': u'114177928', u'id': u'114179315', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JohnFallhammer', u'text': u'Because it's extremely inefficient. They spend most of their time parked, just taking up space, which is often public space. description: A decline in the number of diesel cars would not jeopardise CO2 targets – in fact it would make them cheaper to achieve
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: A decline in the number of diesel cars would not jeopardise CO2 targets – in fact it would make them cheaper to achieve
og_fields.og:title: Pollutionwatch: petrol, not diesel, is less polluting in the short term
text:
The UK Society of Motor Manufacturers blamed February’s rise in the average new-car CO2 emissions on an “anti-diesel agenda [that] has set back progress on climate change”. Petrol v diesel cars is often presented as a trade-off between health-harming air pollution and climate-harmful CO2. Diesel cars do more miles to the litre than petrol, but this exaggerates the difference in CO2 emissions since one litre of diesel contains more energy and more carbon than one litre of petrol. If fuel were taxed on energy and carbon, rather than volume, then the tax on diesel would be 10 to 14% greater than that on petrol.
The International Council on Clean Transportation points out that petrol engines and petrol-hybrids have improved faster than diesel and will continue to do so. They conclude that a decline in diesel cars from around 56% to 15% would not jeopardise EU CO2 targets. Instead, it would make the targets cheaper to achieve since petrol engines cost less to make and have simpler exhaust clean-up. The future might be electric cars (or better yet for public health: cycling, walking and public transport), but in the short term new petrol cars, instead of diesel, might help both climate change and air pollution.

article_tags: [Trump administration, Environment, Climate change, Climate change, US news]
description: Scientists say an internal Environmental Protection Agency document encourages the use of misleading statements about scientific certainty
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Scientists say an internal Environmental Protection Agency document encourages the use of misleading statements about scientific certainty
og_fields.og:title: EPA accused of urging staff to downplay climate change after memo leaks
text:
Scientists have accused the US Environmental Protection Agency of distributing misleading statements about climate change, following the leaking of an internal email advising agency staff to downplay the certainty of the science.
The email, issued by the EPA’s Office of Public Affairs (OPA) and sent out to communications directors and regional public affairs directors, was forwarded to others and shared throughout the agency. The email acknowledges that communities face “challenges” in dealing with the consequences of climate change.
However, the email, obtained by HuffPost, also sets out ambiguous talking points favoured by Pruitt, such as: “Human activity impacts our changing climate in some manner. The ability to measure with precision the degree and extent of that impact, and what to do about it, are subject to continuing debate and dialogue.”
The email adds that “while there has been extensive research and a host of published reports on climate change, clear gaps remain including our understanding of the role of human activity and what we can do about it”.
Joel Scheraga, senior climate adaptation adviser to the agency administrator, Scott Pruitt, was one person to forward the email, which states Pruitt encourages an “open, transparent debate on climate science”.
An EPA spokeswoman said the points were “developed by the office of public affairs. The agency’s work on climate adaptation continues under the leadership of Dr Scheraga.”
Since becoming EPA head under Donald Trump, Pruitt has erroneously denied that carbon dioxide is a “primary contributor” to warming that has seen the Earth’s average temperature increase by about 1C (1.8F) over the past century. Pruitt has also said industrialization has warmed the planet “to a certain degree” but that “humans have most flourished during times of warming trends”.
During his tenure, the EPA has removed information on its website about climate change, scrapped a climate adaptation program and advocated the need for “regulatory certainty” by loosening emissions regulations for vehicles and the fossil fuels industry. A televised “red team, blue team” debate between climate scientists and those who reject the science has also been mulled. 
Pruitt was a vocal supporter of Trump’s decision to remove the US from the Paris climate agreement and is busy dismantling the Obama administration’s clean power plan, which Pruitt fought in court when attorney general of Oklahoma.
Scientists have pointed out that while the exact ramifications of climate change are yet to play out, the science behind it is well established and points directly to human culpability. A major report released by government scientists last year reiterated that humans are the “dominant” driver of global warming, with it being “highly likely” that the release of greenhouse gas emissions has caused more than half of all warming since 1951.
The email forwarded by Scheraga is “literally true but carefully crafted to mislead”, according to Andrew Dessler, a climate scientist at Texas A&M University.
“There is uncertainty in climate science, but the uncertainty spans the range of climate change being somewhat serious to extremely serious,” he said. 
Dessler said any gaps on scientists’ understanding are not big enough to declare climate change a “non-problem”. He added: “And what we can do about it is quite clear: to stabilize the climate, we need to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases to near zero.”
Kerry Emanuel, a meteorologist and climate scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said: “If confronting serious risks depended on first converting risks to certainties, no one would get flu shots, there would be no attempt to reduce stockpiles of nuclear weapons and businesses would fail at a high rate, having made no efforts to mitigate their risks.
“Mr Pruitt is engaged in a disingenuous effort to stall measures to mitigate climate risk under the false pretext of concern about uncertainty.”
The leak comes as it was revealed that Pruitt, already under fire over his use of first class air travel, lived last year in a Washington DC house co-owned by the wife of a leading energy lobbyist.
Property records obtained by ABC News show that Pruitt lived in a townhouse partly owned by Vicki Hart, the wife of Steven Hart, chief executive of lobbying firm Williams and Jensen. Hart’s clients include the NRA and gas company Cheniere Energy. 
“Pruitt’s corruption knows no bounds and he should be fired immediately,” said Michael Brune, executive director of the Sierra Club, one of a coalition of environment groups who have demanded Pruitt be removed from his position.

BQSTART
…when the article in question is quoting a detailed study which says 80% renewables is perfectly feasible?
BQEND
Remember the Caldeira et al paper makes a point of noting that in an 80% renewables system, you still need to keep a backup system of non-renewables capable of handling peak demand (where worst case is the renewable capacity is operating at say 10% nameplate). This naturally isn't viable economically in the real world. And this point is important, since both technical *and* economic limitations need to be taken into account simultaneously. Whatever the lowest bound is (which Finkel didn't take into account), as defined by either of those criteria will be what governs the level of renewables long term - and ends up roughly matching whatever the capacity factor is i.e. ~30%. Which obviously isn't enough decarbonisation. I would definitely be keeping an eye out for when this upcoming paper becomes public:
"Least cost final zero carbon mixes in my forthcoming study rarely close to 80% wind/solar."
It isn't incredulity on my part, simply non-facile rational analysis. I'm not wedded to technologies like nuclear, but some understanding of the technology involved in making electricity, with some economics added in (esp. game theory) and by eliminating the implausible options, you are generally left with tech like nuclear being indispensable to any workable solution.
As far as nuclear is concerned in Australia, there is minimal chance it will be adopted any time soon. But this ultimately means that failure to decarbonise in a meaningful way is most certainly an option here. Well it seems that the Coalition government want to take some responsibility for propping up coal-fired power stations. Christensen and others are demanding the government compulsorily acquire the Liddell power-station. Faced with the prospect that the government may not have the authority to do so, George wants laws changed so the government can buy it and run it. If our government won't run it, then he'd be happy to see it owned by Chinese business.
BQSTART
A group of Coalition MPs are so intent on propping up AGL's ailing Liddell power station they are calling on the Turnbull government to forcibly acquire the coal-fired power plant. 
But Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg all but ruled out the idea on Thursday, insisting the federal government was not going to start nationalising assets.
The charge for intervention is being led by Nationals MP George Christensen, but other MPs are said to have a degree of support for the idea, including former prime minister Tony Abbott and former deputy prime minister Barnaby Joyce.
Mr Christensen told Fairfax Media a compulsory land acquisition would mean the government could run Liddell itself or, if necessary, sell it to interested Chinese giant Shandong Ruyi.
"I don't know whether we have the head of power to actually compulsorily acquire it, but I think it should be absolutely explored. And if we need legislation then that should be considered," he said.
Mr Christensen said he had raised the issue with ministers and was told the intervention would require new laws. "I would encourage that, particularly if the only other option is we lose a coal-fired power station," Mr Christensen said.
He stressed he wanted the federal government to operate the power plant, but selling it to a Chinese buyer was palatable.
BQEND
Not all devotees of coal power are keen to buy Liddell, but would like to see the government build a brand new station of its own. Andrew Broad is one. 
BQSTART
Nationals MP Andrew Broad, who chairs the House of Representatives' Environment and Energy committee, said a compulsory acquisition was not the way to go, but the government could get involved in building an entirely new coal-fired facility
BQEND

I'm encouraged by the recent words & actions of younger people, propelled by the latest school shooting in the US, but almost certainly activated by the rise of vile creatures like Trump. It seems that interest in political activities is on the rise - for too long, we have been stumbling along in "nothing I can do about it" mode, too lazy/comfortable to get off our arses & DO something!
As for the Victorian Liberals, WTF indeed! Bernie Finn has form - in fact, he has similar "rank" (in all senses of the word) in State politics to that of Ian Macdonald in the Senate. After begging & praying in Parliament to be paired because of their religious beliefs, they were granted leave. Finn had come up with "Even when my birthday falls on Good Friday, I do not celebrate it on Good Friday" & Craig Ondarchie offered "This is the day that my Lord was crucified. I do not want to be here".
Yet both returned to vote after Labor had sent two MPs home. This is one of the most hypocritical acts of bastardry ever witnessed in Australian politics!
When you consider Hodgman’s claimed "mandate" for 200 policies not revealed during the Tasmanian election campaign & the dubious pre-vote activities of Steven Marshall in SA, it is frightening to consider how low the Liberal Party will stoop to maintain/gain power.
THEY MUST BE STOPPED!!!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522635014000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'their religious beliefs', u'effect': u'after begging & praying in parliament to be paired'}], u'author_id': u'13137767', u'in_reply_to': u'114231238', u'id': u'114263337', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The above suggests 10 to 1.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522634504000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'114202326', u'id': u'114263284', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NeilofSydney', u'text': u'U may want to read thishttp://www.news.com.au/technology/innovation/motoring/holden-shutdown-general-motors-international-boss-stefan-jacoby-says-australia-is-better-without-car-manufacturing/news-story/af4de2d0090baa6c2a0ce24aa0e28729

With or without government incentives, it doesn’t pencil,” he said. “Even if you add all the (government) incentives … it doesn’t make sense to produce (cars locally).”Mr Jacoby said it was wrong to base a business decision on government incentives alone.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522572976000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14773474', u'in_reply_to': u'114233631', u'id': u'114236440', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Olimadhar', u'text': u'Sorry, you're wrong. Seems like you still think The Emperor is wearing a nice new suit.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522556148000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12229833', u'in_reply_to': u'114231369', u'id': u'114231639', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The Adani mine is one of around 40 new planned coal mines that have yet to built in Australia.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522633669000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'114207203', u'id': u'114263190', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'That the US will meet its Paris commitment despite their appointed president's opposition is a reflection of that bloke's organisational abilities and a triumph of democracy.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522632726000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'114203677', u'id': u'114263099', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EnoughNoMoreLies', u'text': u'Sorry, I couldn't see a Minister with Science in their portfolio. The last one was Sinodinos. That particular Ministry finished in December 2017. Senator Cash now has responsibility for innovation. Ref: https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/Parliamentary_Handbook/Current_Ministry_List
And yet we have Senator Seselja as assistant minister for science, jobs and innovation. Perhaps I missed the actual minister responsible for science.
Lip service by the government to science - or all dispersed so there is no responsibility for science?', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522570995000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14331517', u'in_reply_to': u'114231079', u'id': u'114235488', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Brad Spencer', u'text': u'Who listens to this bozo? he re[presents a minority who really care less about future generations. he gets too much oxygen for me.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522570276000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13667541', u'id': u'114235161', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Beekeeper49', u'text': u'Katharine is correct about the need for a plan, more particularly an energy plan that is not NSW-centric.
In a previous Guardian report we learnt there are many hundreds of sites around this country where pumped hydro could be installed. Why is Snowy 2.0 the only such project being considered? Why can't we share the jobs around by considering other pumped hydro projects? 
One of my concerns about Snowy 2.0 arises out of the Tasmanian experience when an extended drought left water levels low and production of hydro power was adversely impacted. In coming decades, who can be sure that the Snowy won't be similarly affected by drought from time to time? Yet huge funding is going into this one project. 
Because climate change could throw up all sorts of extreme weather events, it makes sense not to place all our energy eggs into one basket. Families and communities need to be more self-reliant. Industry and public transport must not depend on one energy source. And at the same time we MUST address climate change as a matter of extreme urgency. 
And then there is a question of fairness. After the loss of so many Australian manufacturing jobs, Turnbull needs to try harder than to pander only to his home state.
Like you, Katharine, I want to see a plan. The plan I want to see entails a sustainable, affordable, reliable national energy grid that is based largely on renewable energy sources, plus families and communities capable of being self-reliant for domestic needs.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522548202000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14883613', u'id': u'114230608', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GeelongOldF', u'text': u'But this is the myth. Barnacles used to go beetroot telling us how fabulous the Rural Sector had become from FTA exports. This massive up and reeling off others as far as his tongue could recite. So where was the news about in/under employment crashing through the floor, Fly In Fly Outers were so abundant flights couldn't keep up, Wages were sky rocketing, Community businesses were thriving feeding off the export trade, etc. etc. Is isn't happening - trickle down is so illusionary as the Overseas and Pitt Street farmers said what's mine will remain mine', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522555552000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12204485', u'in_reply_to': u'114229841', u'id': u'114231573', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RhondaMay', u'text': u'That was why Murdoch turned against Rudd in 2009 - once he announced the NBN.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522555494000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12229833', u'in_reply_to': u'114213348', u'id': u'114231567', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JimB123', u'text': u'I agree but, he's speaking for the government. If we ignore his inanities we'll be told down the line that it was our fault because they did tell us their plans.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522632723000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they did tell us their plans', u'effect': u'that it was our fault'}], u'author_id': u'13568285', u'in_reply_to': u'114235161', u'id': u'114263097', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Friendship of the kind that arises from people whose morality brought the type of behaviour seen recently in cricket in South Africa and in the Victorian Parliament on Good Friday by the Liberal Party in abandoning the basic decency of the parliamentary pairing convention.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522631483000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'114230003', u'id': u'114262973', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SparkyTheDog', u'text': u'BQSTART
Scott Morrison: Honors degree in Economics!
BQEND
With a Major in Shouting.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522569209000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12898461', u'in_reply_to': u'114233299', u'id': u'114234676', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LocknessMunster', u'text': u'BQSTART
Chinese firms to build 700 coal plants
BQEND
Not any moreYour propaganda is years out of date. They just cancelled and closed 151. Some of them half built. And a lot of the new ones are to replace older much dirtier ones.You sound desperate. China is far and away the world leader in renewable energy.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522569067000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17443130', u'in_reply_to': u'114217592', u'id': u'114234624', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'S_Lionheart', u'text': u'What we are seeing now, from the example of young Sen Matt Canavan latest National Press speech is that, because of the many politicians that has locked themselves in exclusive bunkers accessible only to bankers and businessmen, servile media apparatchik, their own advisers and sycophants of various types - they have lost all sense of reality and become feral, arrogant and hostile towards voters and the fourth estate.
They live in their delusional, half-fake world of money, statistics and focus groups. Their contact with real people, outside election periods, is minimal. Their public face is largely mediated via the mendacious propaganda of the TV networks, or photo opportunities that don’t address issues of inequality and environment of which matters to voters the most. They declined to step down and talk to the people whose worlds they have destroyed. They tend towards paranoia, treating any serious national discussion as disloyalty, and now grow increasingly dependent on spin doctors and fake news to propagandise their policies.
All these have been exacerbated by the now ubiquitous ‘Commercial in Confidence’ principal that has crept into public life from the Howard years until now, denies the community this right, and for no legitimate reason. 
The ‘Commercial in Confidence’ doctrine formalises a shift in the relationship between three of the community’s stakeholders; the government, the community and the corporate sector. The government and the corporate sector are doing deals with each other from which the community - which is paying the bills - is excluded. The community is being sidelined, even treated with contempt.
‘Commercial in Confidence’ rests on the extraordinary premises that private companies have a greater right to know what is happening with the public’s money than the public itself. There is totally no reason why prices of commercial services provided to the public under a government contract should be concealed, any more than the price of bread at the local supermarket should be concealed. What the government is saying when it cites ‘Commercial in Confidence’ is that it owes a sacred duty to protect the interests of business ahead of its obligations to the constituents it is being paid good money to represent.
‘Commercial in Confidence’ culture not only interposes a veil of secrecy between the government and its constituents, it also hides the activity of one part of government from another part of government. Once information is put on the restricted list, it becomes less accessible to anyone and everyone, whether the public at large, civil servants in the bureaucracy or even ministers themselves. A culture of secrecy is installed that throws up barriers everywhere. Bureaucrats can maintain their ministers in the dark the same way that Sir Appleby kept Minister Hacker in the dark in the TV series, ‘Yes Minister’.
Increasing use of the ‘Commercial in Confidence’ principles, raises the inevitable question, if the government has nothing to hide, why go to the trouble of trying to hide it? Whether or not governments invented ‘Commercial in Confidence’ to conduct corrupt dealings with business, corruption is a likely consequence.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522547487000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the many politicians that has locked themselves in exclusive bunkers accessible only to bankers and businessmen', u'effect': u'that they have lost all sense of reality and become feral'}], u'author_id': u'12299894', u'id': u'114230527', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Grumblebum McWombat', u'text': u'BQSTART
Who knows what the actual percentage of gas will be in the end?
BQENDThen why do you assume it will be 50% gas, when the article in question is quoting a detailed study which says 80% renewables is perfectly feasible? Incidentally, Finkel also came to the same conclusion via his own investigations into the Australian grid, as have several other groups in several places.
You seem to have some fixed opinions based on personal incredulity, and use these to pull out whichever figure you like best. This makes you apparently no more rational than the people you are criticising.
I quite understand the necessity for an all-options solution to decarbonisation, and I quite understand that replacing nuclear with gas or coal will be a step backwards in terms of CO2 emissions, as well as being a step backwards in terms of other greenhouse gases like methane. As long as any nuclear plant is on good operating order, and in a stable location, it makes sense to keep using it to reduce emissions.
The current US market, like ours, is unrealistic in that it does not include a price on carbon. This is something we really need to implement as soon as possible, preferably on a consistent international basis. But even then it would be unlikely to lead to large scale adoption of nuclear power, simply because renewables are being built cheaper and faster. Nuclear is only likely to be acceptable in areas which cannot use large scale wind and/or solar.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522546024000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'simply renewables are being built cheaper and faster', u'effect': u'but even then it would be unlikely to lead to large scale adoption of nuclear power'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'large scale adoption of nuclear power'}], u'author_id': u'17605685', u'in_reply_to': u'114230144', u'id': u'114230289', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'wedloik', u'text': u'That would be Fran Kelly and Patricia Kavalas LNP propaganda merchants.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522555391000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13839015', u'in_reply_to': u'114230712', u'id': u'114231550', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'wedloik', u'text': u'Sparky like all toads Caveman should be either put in the deep freeze or meet a number 3 iron.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522554613000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13839015', u'in_reply_to': u'114230889', u'id': u'114231453', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Grumblebum McWombat', u'text': u'The Jenkins analysis you link to does not factor in storage. He admits that changes the parameters somewhat, although he also says it is "not a panacea". I assume by that he means storage is not free and cannot be pulled out of a hat, which is obviously true. Still, it does exist and it is usable. I don't think anyone these days is seriously suggesting renewables without storage.
There's no reason why some storage could not be owned by the companies who are generating power via renewables. In fact that is looking like it will become common, which would mean that the duck curve should be less problematic for company revenues. I'd also expect widespread use of domestic solar plus battery storage, given how it's taking off already, and given that prices for both panels and batteries are still decreasing.
The Jenkins tweet you linked to, and its mention of his upcoming study, says "Least cost final zero carbon mixes in my forthcoming study rarely close to 80% wind/solar". That's interesting, in that he is saying that in some cases 80% wind+solar is the least cost option. He's not saying what those cases are, but apparently they do exist, so as you say is should be a good read.
What is economically viable in the real word depends to some extent on what result we want. It's common to put in place requirements that increase cost if the benefits are seen to be worthwhile. A price on carbon is an obvious example. It makes sense for any decarbonisation policy, but in terms of present day business it is just another cost. It's justified on the basis of its long term benefits to others.
This is going to become a big factor later this century. All the IPCC pathways to <2 degrees C require large (bloody huge) negative emissions in the latter part of the century. That is going to require rolling out some large scale CCS technology, and that is going to cost a lot of money, and pretty obviously it will be funded/incentivised by a high carbon price.. Apparently it has to happen anyway, so in that sense that cost is not relevant. If there's no alternative, you just pay up.
 I also have to say that the privatisation of power generation in this country really does not seem to have been an outstanding success. The Queensland government had to intervene to stop its own subsidiary rorting the spot power market and driving prices sky high, and similar rorting was the reason the SA government wanted control of some of the output from the Hornsdale/Tesla battery. This rorting was perfectly legal under power market rules, and provided better returns for shareholders, but curtailing it was in the public interest even if it wasn't "business-friendly". Power is an essential service, and there are good arguments for not privatising essential services.
Anyway, Jenkins' article says there is no real problem with up to 50% grid-scale wind+solar, even without storage. So, Labor's policy of 50% renewables by 2030 seems perfectly sound as a starting point, particularly when storage is added to the mix. On top of that we have an extra 7% from hydroelectricity (although there are some doubts as to its long term reliability under difficult rainfall patterns). I expect there will also be minor generation from geothermal and biogas (there is some already) so that should bring us close to 60% renewables.
Given that nuclear is not currently feasible in this country, for a variety of reasons, I think Labor's current policy is looking like an excellent place to start. If we need to re-assess things as 2030 gets closer then we (and Jenkins) can do that with the benefit of the better information that will be available by then.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522630262000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17605685', u'in_reply_to': u'114241204', u'id': u'114262837', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RossHosking', u'text': u'The pope is a catholic. What did I say that is wrong. Unfortunately relevance factor zero. Much like your attempts at distraction really.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1522568969000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12104671', u'in_reply_to': u'114210638', u'id': u'114234574', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Empathy is fine from politicians, but truth is better because these communities aren’t stupid
og_fields.og:description: Empathy is fine from politicians, but truth is better because these communities aren’t stupid
og_fields.og:title: Sorry, Matt Canavan, no one believes coal magic means everyone wins | Katharine Murphy
text:
Matt Canavan has an economics degree, graduating from the University of Queensland with first class honours. The Nationals senator and federal minister for resources worked at the Productivity Commission before he entered politics, first as a staffer for his colleague and friend Barnaby Joyce, before being elected to the Senate himself.
The economic pointy head backstory makes Canavan an unconventional National, a fact that doesn’t go unnoticed among his party room colleagues. It also makes some of his public commentary this week just that bit harder to get your head around.
In a busy week, where the government prosecuted but lost an attempt to steer its big business tax cut through the Senate, where Tony Abbott was so desperate for a “look at me” moment he launched Pauline Hanson’s new book, where the nation roiled inconsolably about the behaviour of our cricketers – Canavan fronted the National Press Club to try and generate a couple of headlines of his own.
Canavan, like every other resources minister I’ve seen before him, is an unabashed champion of the mining sector. Boosterism comes with the territory, and the current occupant of the portfolio doesn’t disappoint.
Given every major business sector in the country is pursuing a “please like me” soft advertising campaign of some type – the Business Council of Australia launched one this week, BHP urges us on high rotation to Think Big, the banks have ads specifically to tell customers they aren’t that awful – it was unsurprising to hear Canavan flagging (among other things) efforts to “bolster the community support for the resources sector” including through an “ongoing campaign” to inform people of its benefits.
All just as you’d expect, right down to Stop Adani protesters bursting into the room to puncture his remarks. Where things took an unexpected turn was in the questions, when Canavan raised a balled fist of protest against the future.
Asked whether as federal resources minister (as well as a democratically elected parliamentarian in a representative democracy) he felt an obligation to help Australian communities face up to the inevitability of a carbon-constrained future – Canavan suggested the world needed to stay as it is.
It was “objectionable” he said, to talk about people losing their livelihoods. He said concepts like “just transitions” were a con. “I don’t like the term transition, let’s be frank. If you want to shut down the coal industry and cost people jobs, say it. Have the guts to say it.”
Canavan advised the questioner (which, full disclosure, happened to be me) to take a trip to northern Tasmania to see what a transition really looked like. “Real poverty,” he noted. “House prices halve, people get locked in to an environment they can’t get out of and their lives are destroyed.
“Utter heartbreak.”
You might need to remind yourself at this point of the recount that this is a former Productivity Commission economist talking. If Productivity Commission economists are a foreign species to you, think about people mildly obsessed with transformation, structural adjustment, economic efficiency – that sort of thing.
They are the folks who have been saying for decades in the politest possible way: suck it up soldier, your economy needs you to understand that things change, and the way to get through these adjustments is to pursue evidence-based policy.
Couple of things.
Canavan’s empathy for the coal and power workers – while doubtless sincere at a personal level – is a bit hard to square with his service for a government that shuttered the Australian car industry with barely a backward glance.
I really don’t remember much outward concern for falling house prices, or destroyed lives or “utter heartbreak” in Adelaide. Perhaps some displaced workers are more equal than others.
Then there’s the inconvenient fact that it is his own government’s policy driving the transformation he says shouldn’t happen.
Canavan was part of a government that signed the Paris climate agreement – a set of commitments that make decarbonisation not optional, or hypothetical, but inevitable. Nobody held a gun to the government’s head and made it sign an international agreement to reduce emissions. Abbott might have grumbled at the time, and he engages in active revisionism now, but the fact is he signed Australia up, voluntarily.
If Canavan thinks there should be no adjustment for coal communities, then he’s actually arguing that Australia should quit the Paris agreement – except of course he doesn’t argue that, because that would be problematic for Liberals trying to hold urban seats.
The resources minister attempts to tip-toe through the obvious contradictions by arguing that high-efficiency coal will help reduce reduce emissions and help Australia meet its Paris target. In this happy story, we can reduce our emissions and boost the coal industry too.
But is this happy story true?
While it is self-evidently correct that “clean” coal plants are better in terms of emissions than ageing dirty ones, the minister omits several relevant points. “Clean coal will help us meet Paris” ignores the fact the technology is incredibly expensive; that taxpayers would bear significant risks because clean coal plants are not financeable in Australia unless the government agrees to indemnify projects against the future risk of a carbon price being introduced, and against the cost of delays prompted by likely community protest action. And the electricity grid in Australia is moving inexorably in the opposite direction – towards decentralisation.
There’s one more point that we can make about who should bear the transition. If Canavan thinks coal communities shouldn’t be made to adjust, but it’s OK for Australia to remain in the Paris deal, then he should be arguing in public and around the cabinet table for other sectors of the economy to do their fair share of heavy lifting.
The government is trying to pass off the as-yet-unfinished national energy guarantee as a settled climate and energy policy, which it most decidedly isn’t. Assuming they can land it, this is not mission accomplished. The national energy guarantee is a policy for only one sector of the economy – electricity – and a sector of the economy where emissions are already falling.
Thus far, the government has produced no plans for other sectors of the economy – say transport, or agriculture, where emissions are currently rising – presumably because the Coalition can’t ever have a rational conversation about emissions reduction without someone having a brain explosion.
So what are the facts?
If Australia remains in the Paris agreement, and we honour the undertakings we have made (and the government keeps saying we will do both those things), then a transition is coming.
The transition can’t be avoided. It is already under way.
Ultimately, the question I asked Canavan wasn’t about whether he was intrinsically opposed to the future, but about who takes responsibility for it.
This government, and future Australian governments, will determine whether the transition associated with decarbonisation is fair and orderly and structured, or whether it is chaotic and ugly and deeply unfair to the regional communities the resources minister says he cares about. 
Empathy is fine from politicians, welcome in fact, but truth is better, because these communities aren’t stupid, and they won’t be bought off by facile storytelling that suggests coal magic means everyone wins, and no one has to pick up the tab.
They want to know that someone in elected office is thinking about a new pipeline of blue-collar jobs.
These communities need a plan, and they need political representation with the foresight to give them one, and to do that, our elected representatives have to be very clear about why they are in public life, and who it is they actually represent.

description: I’m standing up with protesters to draw attention to this crisis – I can’t watch while fellow citizens die because of our filthy air, says anti-pollution activist Genny Scherer
og_fields.og:description: I’m standing up with protesters to draw attention to this crisis – I can’t watch while fellow citizens die because of our filthy air, says anti-pollution activist Genny Scherer
og_fields.og:title: London’s air pollution is criminal. That’s why at 71 I’m risking prison | Genny Scherer
text:
For more than 50 years I have loved living in London: but I am now more and more worried about the pollution. I’m worried about the pollution in the water, the pollution in the ground, and the pollution in the air from the busy arterial roads and airports. It’s affecting me and it will affect the crops on my allotment. I have a bike, but in order to go out on a bike now I have to wear a mask which, with my asthma, makes it difficult. When I was arrested last week for spraying “air pollution is criminal” on City Hall, the mayor of London’s office, I was singing “maybe it’s because I’m a Londoner” – I don’t believe Londoners should have to suffer these conditions any longer.
I am taking visible action, and risking time in prison, to pressure our politicians into acting now
People need to be made aware of the issues of air pollution and climate change and start communicating with each other about them. I’m taking this visible action because I want to give people something to talk about; we are calling on the mayor to sit down with community groups and discuss solutions to air pollution. There are already thousands of people in this country and across the world standing up to say now is the time to act on the climate. I am standing up with them, and risking time in prison, to pressure our politicians into acting now.
Along with other clean air defenders, we sprayed “air pollution is criminal” on the walls of City Hall five times last week and were arrested every time. At the police station, the police officers were respectful to us in spite of clearly being overworked and understaffed. In some cases there was even genuine understanding of our action for clean air, even if they did not approve of the methods.
Taking action in the way we did, a kind of “art drama” politics, is a rollercoaster of emotions. Part of me says why bother, why not just enjoy the rest of my life, but my awareness of the danger and future damage won’t let me. I have not given up on provoking people to act on what is happening, to work to cut air pollution and avert climate breakdown. For instance, so far a dozen London community groups have started working in coalition to put increasing pressure on Sadiq Khan to take urgent action. The London Coalition for Clean Air is holding an open introductory meeting on 17 April and I hope that more people and groups will get involved with it. If that happens, then our actions last week will have been worth it.
The mayor should be providing ways for people to get involved and excited about fixing our air pollution crisis – something that is so crucial to the health of all citizens. Money needs to be used to spur people to be creative around technology and to change our cities so we have room for all people to move through them without these deadly health risks. Room for disabled people, room for cyclists, space for people who go slow or fast. I want to see lots of trees, and every house using alternative energy, with plants growing everywhere. Open the parks, don’t close them.
We must get rid of pollution. We need to keep the fossil fuels in the ground. We need an urgent transition; we should all be demanding it and encouraging others to do so too, whether that is through acts of protest, writing to our politicians or talking to our neighbours. This pollution is causing more than 9,000 Londoners to die prematurely every year. Stop killing Londoners.
• Genny Scherer is a 71-year-old anti-pollution activist

description: ‘Time to Choose’ protest demands a fresh focus on renewable energy by the state government
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: ‘Time to Choose’ protest demands a fresh focus on renewable energy by the state government
og_fields.og:title: ‘We want to repower NSW’: thousands rally against coal in Sydney
text:
Exactly a year out from the state election, thousands of people from across New South Wales – including some on horseback – have marched through Sydney, calling for an end to coal seam gas and coal mining and a renewed focus on renewables.
The “Time to Choose” rally, which began at Martin Place, marched to Prince Alfred Park in the city’s south stretching almost 2km along a partially closed Elizabeth Street. 
Neha Madhok, from rally organiser 350.org Australia, said people had come from across NSW “to put the state government on notice”.
“We want the state government and the opposition to know that over the next year we are not going to stop talking about climate change, about coal and gas. We want to repower NSW, we want a renewable energy-powered NSW.”
The state government approved 10 industrial solar farms in 2017 – twice as many as the previous year, and has committed to an ambitious zero emissions target by 2050 as part of its climate change policy framework.
However, legislation has threatened to weaken environmental protections, and several proposed or operating mining ventures have been the targets of long-running community opposition, as well as several applications for extensions.
#time2choose hooray for the farmers pic.twitter.com/hdCkeS10G8
Organisers pointed to the proposed CSG mining in Narribri, open cut coal mining in the Bylong valley, the Southern Highlands Hume Coal project, and Shenhua Mining’s attempts in the Liverpool plains as among the threats to the state’s environment and communities.
“There is no safe place for coal seam gas in NSW. It threatens communities, precious groundwater aquifers and farmland, and the climate, wherever it goes,” said Naomi Hodgson of the Wilderness Alliance.
Glenn Morris, who made headlines in 2016 after riding his horse Hombre across the Sydney Harbour Bridge to raise awareness about climate change, was one of the 25 farmers on horseback.
“There is devastation because of climate change all across NSW,” the Inverell farmer said. “We can’t afford to destroy any more healthy land.”
Bob Clarke came from Wollar, a small village near Mudgee, where he said the open-cut Wilpinjong mine was destroying the region. 
The Peabody mining company was granted an extension last year, but it has been challenged in the land and environment court.
Clarke, who has lived in Wollar for 30 years, said Peabody had recently started buying nearby land, and the exodus of people had “broken the community”.
“There’s only four of us left there now,” he said. “We’re not going nowhere, we’re still hanging in there.”
Bill Ryan, in his 90s, said he wanted governments to realise citizens wanted renewable energy now.
“They’ve got to take into consideration that this is what the people want. So we’ve got to get out and let them know they can’t get away with backing the mining sector all the time. They have to listen to the citizens.”
The Greens MLA David Shoebridge praised the size and breadth of the turnout at the rally.
“We have First Nations peoples, farming communities, inner city environmental and activist groups, all coming together under the same banner.”
Shoebridge said people wanted to put the environment and climate change on the agenda.
“The community is concerned. They’re talking about renewable energy and a fresh way forward that doesn’t involve coal. It’s a concern the parliament is almost entirely deaf to.”
He said there needed to be a “just transition plan” into renewables to support people and communities that relied on industries that had closed.
“We know for a fact that jobs in the coal industry are drying up. Conditions for those workers are getting more and more severe. Meanwhile there is a wonderful opportunity for ongoing solid employment in the renewable energy sector.”
Saddling up to send a message: Murrurundi horseman to saddle up for statewide anti-coal and coal-seam gas rally #Time2Choose https://t.co/E6mWTYQkFB#Farmers for #ClimateAction #Time2Choose pic.twitter.com/dioKJknBQ3
Massive crowd here all with the same message it’s #Time2Choose We must fight to #RepowerNSW. pic.twitter.com/XFAs3vEHvN

[{u'author': u'CommunityMod', u'text': u'Comments on this piece will be closing shortly. Many thanks for your contributions.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521720980000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2902769', u'id': u'113874131', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'While UK agricultural production may be stable as you claim it is insufficient to feed it population which is why that country has had to import food from my country since the 19 century.
On my last days in the UK in March of 2013 we drove north from where some of those starving 19th century immigrants had lived through the green fields of Antrim past the gamboling lambs who had been produced in winter. A few days later we flew out of Belfast just ahead of the blizzard that killed them.
A place that can't grow food in winter is not a good example of a country with good agricultural production.
It's raining here and the sweet potatoes are getting fat. I'll dig them up over the next month and put in some winter vegetables.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521720692000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'113871604', u'id': u'113873904', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'"Climate is not the highest priority"Perhaps you'd like to add something to that bald assertion- facts, arguments, anything at all.?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521719910000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'113870910', u'id': u'113873326', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'My oldest grandson's first love was a very pretty curly blond headed Jewish girls called Noah. They both liked animals.
One of the more interesting stories of climate science denial in Australia also involves Noah's Ark in a way not usually expected. In 1985 self styled US archeologist Ron Wyatt and US marine salvage operator David Fosold using a gadget advertised in treasure hunting magazines an ark shaped structure complete with metal nails on Mt Tendurek in eastern Turkey, 18 km south of Mt Ararat.
In 1985 after completing a survey of Cretaceous tetrapod fossil sites in Queensland, I commenced post graduate studies at the University of Queensland in paleontology and evolution. At the time Queensland was under an undemocratic extreme right wing regime and US creationists were providing hundreds of thousands of dollars per annum finance to local creationists to set up a base here. I went with my supervisor and Ian Lowe to a number of creationist talks to provide some scientific balance. Ian later became President of the Australian Conservation Foundation and an early communicator of the reality uncovered by climate science.

The Horn of Africa consists of the three countries of Eritrea (population 4.475 million, area 117,600 sq km), Somalia (population 14.32 million, area 657,657 sq km) and Ethiopia (population 102.4 million, area 1,100,00sq km). Therefore the Horn of Africa has a total population of 121.195 million people in an area of 1,855,257 sq km resulting in a population density of 65 people per sq km.
The UK has a population of 65.64 million in an area of 242,500 sq km, resulting in a population density of 410 per sq km. The UK has been importing food since the 19th century to feed its population in both good and bad years.
One of the consequences of the increase in the number of heat waves and very hot days due to global warming in the tropical and subtropical parts of the world has been an increase in evaporation hastening the onset of drought by speeding up the depletion of soil moisture. This occurs even in neutral ENSO phase middling years. Global warming is also increasing the frequency of extreme El Ninos years which bring drought to the Horn of Africa.
In the 19th century my partners ancestors left the British Isles to escape famine and starvation even though my country developed fast clippers to bring wheat to their markets. You also claim that "Climate science is faith based." I understand that as a noun faith has two meanings:a) complete trust or confidence in someone or something, andb) strong belief in the doctrines of a religion based on spiritual conviction rather than proof.
So one meaning is about trust while the other is about belief. Trust in the methodologies of science as a practice and profession, may warrant the use of the term "faith" but I doubt that trust is complete in the provisional world of science.
Religion also has two meanings:a) the belief in and worship of a superhuman controlling power especially a personal God or gods, andb) a pursuit or interest followed with great devotion.
As science can be a pursuit or interest followed with great devotion it could be described as a religion in much the same way as Australian Rules Football is described as such. This meaning of "religion" is not to be confused with that of the god botherers.
So climate science is not faith based as the confidence of scientists in the methodologies of science is not sufficiently complete; and climate science is not a religion in the sense of bothering with god things.
So why are you so obsessed with religion? “a higher priority than it objectively warrants.”
BQENDYou claim that my statement is wrong, but you provide no evidence whatsoever that this is the case. And yet far more people are dying from road accidents than from climate change. Bird populations are crashing in many countries, with those in France crashing by more than 70%, according to a recent report referred to in a Guardian article this week. All honey from everywhere in the world now apparently contains traces of neonicotinoids. Patterns of water use in places such as California see inappropriate commercial crop choices conflicting directly with domestic use to an extent that periodically puts people at risk. Mass economic migration has been occurring for some time and shows no sign of abating, resulting in tens of thousands losing their lives in fruitless attempts to reach better lives. The Guardian now reports that the four richest people in the USA owns more wealth than the poorest 50% of the population. Greed and stupidity is resulting in increasing numbers of people being put at risk as a result of a combination of construction in unsuitable areas and modification to catchments that advantage landholders but result in damaging increases in uncontrolled runoff and flash flooding. Population increase in places such as the Horn of Africa has put the environment under such pressure that anything other than a really good year now results in famine and starvation. Changes in technology mean that declining employment will result in potentially very damaging social disruption. And so on.

I don't think so, no. I think an equation is a kind of model. The measurements that are fed into equations are of course produced by instruments. I think Gaston Bachelard says that scientific instruments are the embodiments of theories. Scientific enquiry is only possible if we have a 'model' in which the measurements made by instruments are actually related to things in the real world via a workable model. This is in the same way that the expansion or contraction of mercury is a 'proxy' for temperature. Research requires lots of work and replication and backtracking to produce reliable results, but it is perfectly possible. Everything is a work in progress. There is a naive view that there is some kind of raw data lying around waiting to be discovered - 'Hey I'm a piece of data, so discover me.' Models can be science - I'm very interested in modelling petroleum reservoirs, & I am only too well aware that a reservoir of a few cubic miles is impossible to model
BQEND
And yet oil companies all over the world use such models to plan and develop oilfields, and don't go bust. They even use it to support their SEC Reserves submissions (Exxon Mobil didn't used to - don't know about now - but the SEC accepts the model-based reserves from the others). And you can go to jail for mis-stating SEC Reserves.
Funny that.
Seems like your interest in petroleum models doesn't extend to actually learning something about them. Whereas I've used them and built them. 
They're really just the same as climate models you know. Gridding, finite-difference solvers, temperature and pressure changes, fluid flow, conservation of physical properties, upscaling, downscaling, pseudoization (= parameterisation), forward prediction ((= projection), history matching, 1D, 2D and 3D analytical (= "toy") models to refine parameters or to sense-check processes, fine-scale models which capture the small-scale physics to aid pseudoization or parameterisation, coarse models plugged into a well-pipework-market network (analogous to climate models with economics etc. bolted on).
Perhaps you could start by learning about petroleum models because you won't be put off by "trigger words". 
However first you should learn the basics because without that models can lead you astray.
I recommend Dake's The Practice of Reservoir Engineering. Only £89 from Amazon. It's very well written for a textbook.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1521655438000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"you wo n't be put off by trigger words", u'effect': u'perhaps you could start by learning about petroleum models'}, {u'cause': u'without that models can lead you astray', u'effect': u'however first you should learn the basics'}], u'author_id': u'18522661', u'in_reply_to': u'113845314', u'id': u'113849798', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQSTART
As discussed in Chapters 1 (Section 1.4) and 12 (Section 12.2), climate projections are subject to several sources of uncertainty. Here three main sources are distinguished. The first arises from natural internal variability, which is intrinsic to the climate system, and includes phenomena such as variability in the mid-latitude storm tracks and the ENSO. The existence of internal variability places fundamental limits on the precision with which future climate variables can be projected. The second is uncertainty concerning the past, present and future forcing of the climate system by natural and anthropogenic forcing agents such as GHGs, aerosols, solar forcing and land use change. Forcing agents may be specified in various ways, for example, as emissions or as concentrations (see Section 12.2). The third is uncertainty related to the response of the climate system to the specified forcing agents.
BQEND

Over the past decade, we have been collaborating with Ben Santer at LLNL (along with numerous other investigators) to compare our tropospheric results with the predictions of climate models. Our results can be summarized as follows: 
 Over the past 35 years, the troposphere has warmed significantly. The global average temperature has risen at an average rate of about 0.18 degrees Kelvin per decade (0.32 degrees F per decade). Climate models cannot explain this warming if human-caused increases in greenhouse gases are not included as input to the model simulation. The spatial pattern of warming is consistent with human-induced warming. See Santer et al 2008, 2009, 2011, and 2012 for more about the detection and attribution of human induced changes in atmospheric temperature using MSU/AMSU data.
 
But....
 The troposphere has not warmed quite as fast as most climate models predict. Note that this problem has been reduced by the large 2015-2106 El Nino Event, and the updated version of the RSS tropospheric datasets.
BQEND
BQSTART
One possible explanation is an error in the fundamental physics used by the climate models. In addition to this possibility, there are at least three other plausible explanations for the warming rate differences. There are errors in the forcings used as input to the model simulations (these include forcings due to anthropogenic gases and aerosols, volcanic aerosols, solar input, and changes in ozone), errors in the satellite observations (partially addressed by the use of the uncertainty ensemble), and sequences of internal climate variability in the simulations that are difference from what occurred in the real world. We call to these four explanations “model physics errors”, “model input errors”, “observational errors”, and “different variability sequences”. They are not mutually exclusive. In fact, t here is hard scientific evidence that all four of these factors contribute to the discrepancy, and that most of it can be explained without resorting to model physics errors.  For a detailed discussion of all these reasons, see the post on the Skeptical Science blog by Ben Santer and Carl Mears, and the recent paper in Nature Geoscience by Santer et al.
